description:
My bf was craving a breakfast burrito (bb)and saw Sun Rise listed on Foursquare as one of the best spots for bb in SF. We got there around 9:30am and were seated right away. We both ordered the Vegan BB, which comes with soyrizo, black beans, sliced avocado, and potatoes; with salsa on the side.  Let me be clear, were not disappointed! The burrito is about 6" long and pretty heavy. It has a nice balance of ingredients, and the salsa on the side is perfect for individual adjustment of spice.

The only negative feedback I could give was actually something my bc mentioned, which is that the yellow paint on the walls is a bit much. 

Other then that 5 stars!
author: Seumanu D.

description:
A mom and pop shop if I've ever seen one, with all the charming and endearing qualities you'd expect. The atmosphere is home-y and quiet, almost like you're sitting in a grandmother's kitchen. 

The vegan breakfast burrito at Sun Rise is probably my favorite I've had maybe anywhere thus far in SF. It comes loaded with potatoes, black beans, avocado, soyrizo and a side of homemade salsa. It's pretty hefty -- enough to fill my girlfriend and I up and hold us over until lunch time. 

The vegan tamales here are also very good. They're moist and flavorful, perfect if you're craving tamales but having trouble finding vegan options. 

I love the menu at this cozy, casual spot and I'm looking forward to trying their other vegan options! Assuming, of course, I can ever bring myself to try something besides the breakfast burrito. 

Give this lovely, family owned and run restaurant your business -- you won't regret it.
author: Alex K.

description:
Great option for Vegans or Vegetarians. Glad that it opens up early

Tried the Vegan French Toast and Vegan Burrito and got the Vegan Fajitas and a few pupusas to-go

French Toast - Did NOT really like the taste and it was pretty dry, liked that it came with a lot of fruits which looked fresh.

Vegan Burrito - Had beans, fries, avocados, tofu and was very tasty

Vegan Fajitas - This had Tofu with a bunch of veggies in a spicy sauce, served with rice and beans. This was very flavorful but kind of expensive ($16.95) for a vegan dish.

Pupusas - These were not that great. I got 1 each of the Vegan options which were spinach, zucchini and lorocco with beans. But the pupusas were 95% beans and tiny pieces of the other ingredient. So was not a fan of the pupusas.

But I loved the fact that they have several vegetarian / vegan options.
author: Umang D.

description: Vegan Breakfast Burrito was delicious! Service was fast. No wait around weekday breakfast time. Clean bathroom. Friendly staff.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Sun Rise is the type of restaurant that makes San Francisco awesome.  A small, family run business, with delicious dishes and friendly service. They even have several vegan dishes, like the soyrizo burrito that is delicious.  I was sad to see that their landlord increased their rent by $3,000/month recently.  

It was be a great shame for Sun Rise to go out of business because of the rent increase.  I hope everything works out for Sun Rise!  Please go eat their to help support a great local business!
author: Paul W.

description:
Best vegan breakfast burrito in the city!

Platanos, papusas, french toast vegan options as well.

Welcoming vibe and kind staff, we will be back regularly.
author: Mike G.

description:
Beware!
This place is a royal rip off.! We checked out their online menu and ordered 12 pupusas  ; when we went to pick up , they charged us almost double the price , stating that they had recently "updated" their prices. We were hungry so we just paid- The place was empty, we should 've known, this is the last time we order or go to this dump.! The pupusas were greasy and small. 
Don't dine at this place!
author: Mark C.

description: Eggs, chorizo and black beans.  A bit pricey for what you get.  $15 for what seemed like a kids meal and not much egg in the chorizo.  It was tasty and a quick hunger fix.  Not a place I would make my regular stop.
author: Cyprian S.

description: My partner and I stopped here will visitingnSam Francsico. I am vegan and my partner is vegetarian, and we had multiple options. We ordered the vegan french toast and the vegan tofu scramble (pictured) and split it. The tofu scramble was amazing.. well-seasoned tofu with spinach, zucchini, tomato, onion, mushroom, and peppers. It came with some big homefries (about 1 cup worth), 2 slices of toast with an amazing strawberry jam, and was garnished with orange and apple slices (I also used the tapatio hot sauce provided yummm). The french toast was made with soy milk and came with diced fruit on top (apple, orange, banana, strawberry). This little hole-in-the-wall was a great find, especially after finding it tough to locate a vegan breakfast place in San Francisco that also offers multiple nut-free options. It can be frustrating being a vegan with a nut allergy, so I was extremely pleased to come here. The food was delivered in a timely manner and the waitress was attentive, kind, and accommodating (e.g. brought me soy milk for my coffee). Great place!
author: Whitney M.

description:
I just went here tonight for the first time to watch my friend play music. The food was so delicious-- Really fresh Mexican and Salvadorean cuisine prepared with care. Also had some great vegan
dishes, like fajitas with Tofu and very flavorful black beans. There is something for everyone there. 
The staff is also very friendly
Im going back soon!
author: Sophie O.

description: I love Sun Rise Restaurant. I went to elementary school a few blocks from Sun Rise, and considering how much the Mission has changed and been gentrified, the existence of Sun Rise is a both a blessing and a testament to their fantastic food and community importance. As a vegan it can be difficult to do breakfast (yes, even in San Francisco), but when I feel like going out I always want to come to Sun Rise. I'm a huge fan of the vegan breakfast burrito, and having some plantains on the side is that much better. I haven't been back for lunch but I really want to!! Vegans, there are explicitly vegan options available for vegan breakfast so COME HERE! No frills, authentic, super delicious, filling, and reasonable prices. Put your money where your mouth is and support places like these!!! Unfortunately they're a dime a dozen in the mission now a days.
author: Becca C.

description: Platano frito on point! Salvadoran horchata hella good.  Pupusas melt in yo mouth. Come support this awesome local business.
author: Edith C.

description:
Vegan burrito 
Huevos rancheras
Chan drink

We loved the food

It's too expensive
author: Foodlover B.

description: Delicious Breakfast burritos and pint glass mimosas!!!!!! Plus it's close to my house so I can roll home after
author: Ali E.

description:
This amazing find has the best sopa de
res and gallina w / fresh veggies and bone broth. They are plagued by doubled rents and need folks to support their new evening hours.
author: Annette G.

description: I still dream about vegan breakfast burrito here from last week!  Fantastic place that I would frequent if I was a local
author: Caroline D.

description:
Cheap, tasty, vegan options! What more could a girl want? 
Cozy atmosphere like a diner breakfast experience you want on a chilly Saturday morning in the mission. Quick simple service. 
Nothing fancy! Just yummy! 
Try the Vegan Breakfast Burrito with a double espresso! Woohoo!
author: Emily H.

description: Hell yeah VEGAN TAMALES AND PUPUSAS!!! Go here! Great place, super friendly staff, delicious vegan food options. SO glad I stumbled across this on yelp!!!
author: Stephanie W.

description: This hAs been my local gem in the mission district. Authentic food and very welcoming friendly staff and service. I hope it stays here forever, pleAse support this local business.
author: Julia ..

description: the ambiance is very homey and intimate, it feels like you're eating at your abuelita's house. the food arrived very quickly and was delicious! the tofu plates are perfect for vegans and vegetarians. the vegan pupusas are fresh, savory, without grease, and definitely not salty! the owner was very kind, and considerate/attentive for vegan diets. the food was plated very well, and everything was made with delicious, fresh ingredients. overall it was one of the best breakfast experiences i've had! highly recommend for omnivores and herbivores, if you're craving a delicious latin-inspired meal.
author: Anna S.

description: This is a hidden gem. But the crowd is mostly non-Latino/a. The restaurant staff seem to be mostly Salvadorean. On a recent visit, most people seemed to be ordering regular breakfasts. We were the only table having Salvadorean food. My GF likes rhbecause the pupusas aren't greasy. My family prefers a legit Salvadorean place and prefer the greasier pupusas. I shall take my non-latino, vegetarian friends here (lots of vegetarian options) and my family to La Santaneca de la Mission (Mission at 24th).
author: Rude G.

description: Sun Rise is a little restaurant with friendly servers and very fair prices. The owner has high standards for cleanliness and healthy food. She offers a variety of vegetarian and meat dishes and uses fresh ingredients to serve up dishes that are not greasy. She is a humble and hardworking chef whose health-conscious approach to delicious food is born not of any culinary trends but her love of feeding her family in that way.
author: Doriana B.

description: Delicious El Salvadorian food, and very vegetarian friendly. Warm environment with a really nice owner. They're now hosting private parties too!
author: Hannah A.

description: Great food and great place. They also really cater to vegetarians and vegans, which I really appreciate. We had pupusas, plantains, and a vegan burrito, damn, so good!
author: Bradley A.

description: It's hard to find vegan pupusas and tamales and they offer it! Nice selection of meals and side orders to pick from.
author: Mary B.

description: Such a great brunch experience! The vegan breakfast we ordered was delicious, filling, and was very affordable. Our host who is also the owner was kind, attentive, and considerate of our vegan needs. The atmosphere is inviting and feels like home. It was delicious and one of my new favorites!!
author: Lulu K.

description: Their website has not been updated in 10yrs, according to the owner lady. Online my breakfast said its $6,50 and when I got there i was shocked that it was 8.99...plus tax. When I asked why the website has different pricing she said "its not been updated in 10yrs". Good to know to bring extra money so you arent short when you get there.
author: Isa S.

description: Been going her for years.  So sad that because gentrification , her rent has been raised $3000 A MONTH and she will probably end up closing just like everything else in our home. It's hard being an sf native these days.  :( huevos al Gusto is my fav go here and support plz
author: Georgia C.

description: Exactly what you would expect when you walk in! Somewhat slow inattentive service, but overall friendly. Food was decent; I got heuvos rancheros. Would eat here again!
author: A P.

description:
Cute little breakfast spot in the middle of Mission. Had huevos Mexicana with a glass of horchata. The horchata was fantastic and one of the best I've ever had!

Perfect for a quick breakfast or lunch. Highly recommend if you're in the area. Definitely try some of the "Sabor Latin". Enjoy!!
author: Matt B.

description:
I came here for the first time today for brunch and I was so glad I picked it out of all the other places we were looking at in the Mission. They have all the Latin breakfast staples, as well as classic Salvadoran dinner entrées, including pupusas. They have also an expanded breakfast menu to include omelettes, benedicts, and the like.

I got the chilaquiles and they did not disappoint. It was perfectly flavored which help me get over the fact that it doesn't come with chicken at this spot. Friends got pupusas, huevos a la Mexicana, and tamales and all liked their dishes as well. 

I was a little sad to see that they have things like different vegetarian pupusas, but didn't have some other typical options like loroco. Perhaps catering to their usual crowd! Understandable in the Mission.

All in all, love this spot and can't wait to come back.
author: Neda S.

description: Went here on a weekday morning because I read they have vegan-friendly​ options. The restaurant offers Latin​ and American​ cuisine for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. The owner was very nice and greeted us as soon as we came in. We ordered the vegan french toast, huevos rancheros, side of hash browns, and bacon. I enjoyed my french toast and my fiance enjoyed his food as well. It all taste fresh and homemade. I noticed there's a sign on the door asking for donations to keep their business running. Their landlord raised their rent to $3,000 a month which is the equivalent of an extra $36,000 a year and on top of that the owner has to have surgery soon. That made me sad, I hope the owner can keep this business running afloat; it would be a shame to see this restaurant go out of business. Support small business owners! Come here and try all the delicious food. I will be coming back as often as I​ can and will bring visitors here as well. Next time I'll try their vegan burrito and vegan pupusas.
author: Cristal F.

description: Stopped by for an early morning breakfast on Sunday, and while the place was very charming and the staff very nice, my order for two eggs and sausage was very poor; first off it only appeared to be one egg and the sausage was a giant chunk with fat on the bottom so that it was difficult to cut. Tiny portions. Maybe I just came on an off day but cannot recommend at least for breakfast. Very disappointed.
author: Danny B.

description: This place is a sweet local favorite for brunch (I almost hesitate to blow their cover but why not share the wealth?!) I take vegan friends here for the papusas and although I'm not vegan. The plantains are not to be missed. Their black beans have flavorful subtlety that should be noted. The staff are super sweet and kind humans. Treat yourself to this little Mission spot soon.
author: Carey L.

description: Great place for breakfast. Eggs rice beans hot tortillas all good. Loved their pupusa revuelta lots of filling.
author: L C.

description:
So I was with my children on the Day of the Dead celebration and by the time we got to the 24th Street Mission drag of the march we were famished.  Surprisingly it wasn't crowded and we took our seats and ordered their famous pupusa platters (thick deep fried handmade tortilla filled with, in our case, spinach.)  It took them a while to take our order and were even glacial in bringing-out the food. But once we started digging into the spinach pupusas we realized that it was well worth the wait.  The black beans were so tasty and salty and my family dipped their pupusas into the salty bean sauce as a sort-of dipping sauce - decadent.  Their curtido salad (lightly fermented cabbage slaw with red chilies and vinegar) felt light and healthy and digestibly spiced nicely.  The pupusas themselves? Tasty and above average but not phenomenal.  The biggest problem I had with the place was the price.  These platters would normally go for much, much cheaper in an authentic hole-in-the-wall central American restaurant in the mission district, probably 1/3 the price if you find a low rent family run operation.  We ordered three pupusa platters with, after looking at their prices on the menu, water... and it still came-out to $45.  We contemplated standing up and leaving because of the value restaurant impression bait-and-switch bit didn't.  The price may not seem so bad by normal standards I guess, but simply by the look of the place you thought good value/good food; looks can be deceiving.  So in a nutshell:  tasty but a semi-ripoff.  If they want excellent marks, and repeat customers, all they need to do is charge 6-something for your platters not 9-something.  But I have to give it to them: they have a lot of vegan options, serving breakfast all day, so props.  Also, the servers were nice.  

They squeak the third star because of their menu diversity but the restaurant pricing leaves a lot to be desired.  If you are a hole-in-the-wall, even a cute/clean hole-in-the-wall, on 24th Street, you need to price as such.  I can imagine that if we ordered drinks the bill would have been in the $60 range.  Their pricing removes it from the category of "daily cheap-eat/frequent order" restaurant like Poncho Villa burrito-like everyday food and places it in the rare special occasion restaurant category.

Note to Management: Pupusas are not supposed to be pricey.
author: Khash C.

description: Excellent vegan chorizo burrito! Very cozy spot. Nice artwork on the wall! The prices are very reasonable. Friendly neighborhood and the service was great :) thank you!
author: Kristofer C.

description: I just ate their vegan breakfast burrito & thought it was delicious!  Their tortillas are slightly chewy, the soyrizo was tasty & the addition of home fries & avocado to the black bean base was just right. Price was right too!
author: M O.

description: I got the vegan pesto scramble which was pretty good but smaller tofu bites and some bigger veggies Microsoft fed them n would have been nice.  My co-eater got the vegan chorizo burrito was terrific. I almost ordered it but love pesto too, glad we shared!  Both plates seemed a bit sparse looking when served, other non vegan dishes served seemed to be a bit fuller with sides. This isn't to say we didn't get enough food, was totally stuffed.
author: Vegan D.

description:
Sooo good! Came here with my boyfriend for brunch and we got the breakfast burrito and the huevos con chorizo.

Pros:
-Fast service
-Great coffee!!
-Cool area

Cons:
-Smaller portion than anticipated, but still a great deal. We both came out full from our meal.

We would definitely come here again!
author: Michiru K.

description: My go to breakfast when I don't want to go far from home. I love the Huevos Al Gusto - eggs your way :D comes with plantains, beans, rice and tortillas to wrap everything up.
author: Joel D.

description: Food was ok. Cute inside. I got a breakfast burrito and side of bacon. Bacon was bomb.
author: Gabby O.

description: I liked this place the moment I walked in. The yellow-colored walls are filled with sunshine. I ordered the veggie burrito. It was really delicious and perfectly sized. They have a variety of Latin-American dishes here.
author: Guillermo M.

description:
I used to work at the General. That's how I stumbled upon Sunrise. When I first moved up to the Bay, coming to Sunrise reminded me of home cooked meals at my best friend's house in LA (beans, chilaquiles, burritos, plantains, oh my!) I never had a bad experience before today's visit -- and I could not be more bummed about it. First, the food itself tasted fine (we ordered chilaquiles and plantains) ... but it took a tortuous amount of time before our food came. 

We arrived to a short wait (about 3 parties of ahead) and were seated after 15 minutes. We had a game plan (let's share chilaquiles and plantains so we can stop by Philz after) ... but no one came to take our order for over 10 minutes. (We were seated next to the register, so this isn't a "you're seated in the corner and I will conveniently ignore you situation.") Ok, that was weird, but I suppose the restaurant is busy. We order. 

And now the waiting game... I kid you not ... at least 40 minutes passed before we got our food. Now I've been trying to live a more zen life, where I don't do things like, stare at all of the plates leaving the kitchen angrily and anxiously hoping that they're mine -- and I didn't ... for the first 30 minutes. That last 10 minutes (or however long it was), I had run out of resources and boy, was I hungry and anxious to be fed. At the rate that they were serving food today, I really thought that 90% of their kitchen was not functioning. 

But even then, it took forever to get our bill (even though most of the restaurant was gone by then...) and even longer to get our change. No sense of urgency from the staff and no basic customer service provided ("how was your meal? Everything ok?"). I can't say that the food is good enough to endure almost an hour of unnecessary, impatient, confused waiting. With so many other options in the Mission (and in SF, in general), I probably won't be back :(. Bummer.
author: Jane L.

description: Delish!  Their menu has many American and Latin choices.  They also serve breakfast all day!  Not to mention the prices are very affordable.  They also serve barista style coffee and wine/beer.
author: Frisco T.

description: The food is so yummy and the people are so warm and friendly. The menu has a really great selection and everything I've had is delicious. I eat here all the time and will continue to.  Eating here is a great way to start your day!
author: Win A.

description: Went for breakfast. Lots of vegetarian and even vegan options. Ordered papusas. Fast and friendly service. Overall really good! And they open early!
author: JV V.

description: We were a little worried because no one was in there. But we decided to try it anyways. Delicious and friendly! I had Huevos Al Gusto and a side of plantains.  My son had the breakfast burrito.  He loved it!  Homestyle vibes.
author: Kristine S.

description: Had the lomito plate with a cup o joe.  Large portion, good veggie-Meat ratio, tasty.  Sauce was a lil salty.  Black beans were good, too.  Coffee was freshly brewed.  V happy they threw in some queso fresco.  Nice atmosphere and friendly service.
author: Gonzalo S.

description: This place was super cute and small( which makes me feel like a found a diamond in the rough!) they are a Latin based restaurant but we went there because they offer several different vegan options! I got the vegan breakfast burrito and it was AMAZING! San Francisco has some of the best vegan chorizo I've had! My fiancé had the vegan French toast and it was also amazing! They have like one or two more vegan options as well! We also ordered mimosas and they were HUGE!! Everything about this place was awesome! The women that waited on us was so nice and fast and the whole experience was great!
author: Kelsey M.

description:
If you've got a hankering for home cooked food - but miles away from Momz, Tia or Abuelita - Sun Rise will surely satisfy that craving! Un cafecito con cremita to start your order and you'll be knock, knock, knockin' on heaven's door. Also, their huevos rancheros is the closest I've ever come to Momma's cookin'. It hits the spot EVERYTIME! Dare I mention their vegan burrito? Even if you're not vegan, this burrito will leave your mouth watering for more. 

It always feels like famila when I make my way in here. From the decor on the walls, to the friendly staff, to the panaderia right next door, Sun Rise is most definitely my home away from home!
author: Flor K.

description: This restaurant is amazing, very cozy, good prices and portions. The location is perfect and the staff it's really great
author: Ernesto R.

description: Bad service, not on top off coffee runs or refill water, food is not great way better spots in the mission  don't waste your cash real talk... give it 2 stars because I like the carnival pics on the wall...
author: Antonio V.

description:
Where can I start?  Oh yeah,  20 fucking minutes to get take our order in?  Are you kidding me?  Tried to get the servers attention  several times,  a someone came by to clean the table next to us and asked for assistance to no avail.  

Had  to walk away from this place hungry due to them serving people who arrived after us and their staff completely  ignoring our table that was next to the window...  Never again for this place,  there is no excuse for lousy ass service in the city.
author: Daniel A.

description: Absolute favorite place to have breakfast. Really reasonably priced and absolutely delicious and authentic.
author: Kassi K.

description: Y'all. This place does not advertise as being somewhere you can eat if you are vegan and gluten free, and the online menu doesn't even have the full menu. I got HOOKED UP. Fried Plantains, black beans, veggie corn free papusas made with rice flour, breakfast potatoes, avocado - I was able to order so much, I can't even remember it all. And the price was so affordable. 10/10 would recommend!
author: Melissa M.

description:
Seating: Plenty of room. ****
Service: ** ok. Took awhile for food to come for 4 people, no one else in the restaurant, after we were there for about an hour we were offered seconds on coffee.
Speed food to table: **
Correct Order *****
Presentation *** Portions were very small
Taste:  *** fair
Ambience: ***** Very homey, great paintings.
Coffee: *** Served from Giant coffee thermos
Potatoes : **** Pretty good
Overall Rating ***
author: Jj K.

description: Stumbled upon this place and decided to go in because it was full of people. Kinda reminds me of a homier version of a diner. Lots of options, friendly service. Ordered the huevos Mexicana. The cheese and beans are super good, and the eggs were excellent. Tasted a bit of my friend's steak meal, and that was insane! Kinda wish I had ordered it myself. I also got a chicken tamale, and I really liked it. I think I'd go back. Prices are quiet reasonable.
author: Jen A.

description:
"Sunrise, Sunrise. Feels like mornin' in your eyes." As Norah Jones once stated in her eponymous song, I'm pretty sure she was talking about Sun Rise Restaurant when she harmonized those beautiful words.

I can't think of a better way to wake up when you are craving a delicious Vegan Mexican inspired breakfast. I can't believe I had this place bookmarked for nearly a year before my sweetie and I had the chance to sample the soyrizo-fueled goodness.

They don't only specialize in south of the border dishes. I had their Vegan French toast on my mind for quite some time since I first browsed their menu online. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sun-rise-restaurant-san-francisco-2?select=EBX4ZIu43NiGocJSaJ-poA#VG81GjehrQ28oFRGfzSSdA I can't remember the last time I had a Vegan French toast in a restaurant. My only experience is with the homemade variety. I have to admit this one is more authentic than my homemade version, if less substantial. I feel I've gotten used to the heavily battered Vegan version, thus I prefer it. (Sidenote: I know I just created myself some work because my girl knows I can make French Toast now) Not saying I wouldn't order this again. Just saying don't come here expecting to get full off this alone. I would like to see them use a thicker bread to make the French Toast.

In fact, skimpy portions seem to be par for the course here. This tofu scramble looked downright meager. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sun-rise-restaurant-san-francisco-2?select=EBX4ZIu43NiGocJSaJ-poA#HcA_Y3RfmtezxAfHpifJ_w I think I'm used to seeing huge plates served for breakfast/brunch that it's a bit disappointing at first. In the end, after finishing it all, we were quite fulfilled without being stuffed to the brim. I can't hate on a restaurant that is trying to look out for my girlish figure... What I CAN hate on is the flavor. Much more bland than most I've had. It wasn't terrible but if you're gonna choose quality or quantity, you need to choose at least one of them. 

I was hesitant to order their full soyrizo plate, believing it was the usual stuff you'll find in TJ's or Whole Foods refrigerator section. We got a side order to go with the scramble. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sun-rise-restaurant-san-francisco-2?select=EBX4ZIu43NiGocJSaJ-poA#eug8ozm5p1p5r-jpilXZdw I'm glad we did because it ended up being the best thing on our table. Nicely spiced and quite homemade looking. I'll certainly opt for the full plate with beans, rice, & salsa next time.

Their Mr. Espresso coffee is seriously "wake the heck up" strong. I'm sensing "espresso" isn't just a moniker. I normally drink my coffee black. That wasn't happening with this one. I had to make liberal use of the soy creamer provided. 

Service was really good except for the fact she couldn't deduce that we are Vegan based on our order. She brought out dairy cream with the coffee. No harm as we asked her and she apologized while bringing the soymilk. I just figured with the amount of hipsters that come through here, she would know by now. Over all, the service was actually really good.

With a breakfast burrito on their menu, we'll be back to try that as well as the soyrizo plate. If that's as good as I'm thinking, consider this a full 4/5 star review. Until then it's 3.5 for now, but I feel like rounding up today.
author: John B.

description: For some reason I expected the mushroom omelette to be spectacular but unfortunately it wasn't. All I got was below average and no love was put into the food. The plate is overpriced for its bad quality as well. I am not judging the whole menu just because one item was terrible but as far as this plate goes, it's not so far. The restaurant's atmosphere was okay but nothing too interesting. The service was not too bad but it did seem as if it were lacking some organization.
author: Yobani G.

description:
First day of school for the kids meant a breakfast date with Daddy! I came for the chilaquiles! I've never had it before.  They did not disappoint! 

Great service and a well known neighborhood spot! My husband knew half of the patrons! 

The orange juice was fresh and the breakfast burrito hubby ordered was pretty tasty! We will be back to try other items!
author: Candy R.

description: I love their breakfast burritos, but do I wish they had more? Yes! The pupusa's are also great.
author: James T.

description:
One of my go-to spots when I don't want to wait in long lines for brunch! 

The pupusas here are my favorite non-pizza way to satisfy my pizza cravings. Although I suppose you can make the argument that they are akin to an ancient Mayan pizza (move over, Naples!). Basically, pupusas are a thick and crispy pan-fried masa tortilla stuffed with meat/cheese/veggies. I'm a huge fan of the loroco (a slightly bitter-tasting flower) + cheese as well as the revuelta (mixed) pupusas. Definitely order 2-4 of these as a side dish to share.

I usually don't order vegan at restaurants but their soyrizo is actually quite good. The odd thing is that they serve the vegan breakfast burrito on a huge plate with just a side of salsa. Really makes the burrito look smaller than it is and they definitely waste a lot of precious plate real-estate. Wish they would also serve some side salad or avocados with their burritos!

It's usually easy to get a table for 4 on weekends without much wait, but you end up losing that gain due to their slow service/long cooking time.
author: Arushi S.

description: Delicious vegan American and Latin American breakfast treats. Probably have come here a dozen times now. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. When I'm feeling extra hungry, or I have a friend who likes to share, I get the vegan chorizo scramble with a side of plantains and avocado, a side of vegan French toast, and a pupupusa to round it all out.  The ambiance is simple and cozy. Coffee and chia juices are delicious. Love their service and the fact that you can stay for as little or  as long as you want.
author: Danielle P.

description:
I would give this a 3.75 if I could.  The only thing keeping me from giving 4 stars is because the place is small, decor is not great and could be done so much cuter.  However, the food was very good.  But I try to reserve my 4's for places that really, really impress me.  I was definitely impressed - but not wowed.  : ) We went for breakfast on New Year's Day.  We had to wait about 20 min to be seated (3 of us).  Service was good - bringing food out however, was a little slow.  With all that said, here's what we ordered:

1. Huevos Rancheros - this dish came with black beans, queso fresco (would have liked a slightly larger piece) and steamed tortillas on the side.  The slightly fried tortilla that came under the eggs was probably one of my favorite parts of the meal.  It was slightly fried, not soggy at all and gave the dish a really nice flavor and texture.  l also liked the fresh and pleasingly light sauce and cheese that they placed on top of the eggs.  It wasn't too tomatoey - which I liked.  Sometimes when I've ordered at other places it tastes like they poured a can of diced tomatoes on top - but not here.  Sauce was nice and had good flavor.  We also ordered a side of fried plantains which went really well with this dish - so - go for it!

2.  Chilaquiles - had a bite of my daughter's meal and I have to say..it .tasted WAY better than it looked.  Yummy chorizo flavor and overall just really tasty.  She ordered a side of avocado and fried bananas and seemed to enjoy this addition to the meal.

3.  Horchata - we all got the horchata to drink.  It was good, nice and cold from the ice.  A little sweeter and less "spicy" than most horchatas but good.  Spicy isn't really the word I'm looking for but those who drink horchata probably know what I'm trying to get at.  We had coffee too - which was fine.

Would definitely come back for either of these breakfast meals and everyone who worked there was very nice and accommodating.
author: Rachael C.

description:
This place is close to my apartment and it's great! 
The authentic Mexican dishes are fresh and healthy and the service is great! 
The prices are also very reasonable, so I go here multiple times every week.
I would love to see some more dessert options though aside from just the Salvadorian cake and the sweet corn and milk drink that they have.
author: Sahil S.

description: Sunrise is BY FAR one of my favorite places to eat. It's cozy, the service is AMAZING and the food is so.ridiculously.good!!!! Mmmm mmm Mmm!! So grateful for the vegan options!
author: Victoria A.

description:
At long last, a restaurant in SF that understands that tofu scrambles need fat, too. And salt. Give me hypertension, or give me death. 

For my boyfriend specifically (and others like him), they have chicken dishes to order at 8am and also, inexplicably, keep wood in the back of the joint. These are his two primary interests (i.e., chicken dishes, wood) so needless to say, we won't be leaving for a long time (hence the reason that I am writing this Yelp review now, still seated at the table as he considers woodworking projects).

Also, I didn't need to sell my firstborn to get a reso and/or pay the bill; that's a rare plus, too (I have sold a lot of firstborns from dining in this town, is what I am saying).
author: Crystal C.

description:
I loved the pupusas and chicken tamale, really very fresh and authentic mexican flavor, I was nicely surprised!! Coffee muy bueno too!! 

I would highly recommemd it and will love to come back in another visit to SF ;)
author: Claudia N.

description: The family had breakfast at the Sunrise Restaurant and it was great. Service was friendly food portions were just right and very well done. Atmosphere was fine for a small family restaurant. No complaints
author: Ted B.

description:
Have you ever believed you would like a restaurant before you even try it? This was the case for Sunrise. It did not disappoint. 

Everything is on point. As a vegetarian, there's many tasty veggie options. The tofu pesto scramble is very good! I think Los Panchos in bernal heights has the best papusas. The papusa here is okay. 

The service is great and the ladies are sweet. I can't believe people complain about the decor. What do you expect on 24th st?! People are seriously first world. I think the decor is adorable and takes me to another place not in Mission, in San Francisco. 

Try it out. Really good
author: Rachel T.

description:
I may not be giving this place a fair rating since I just went in randomly for lunch and just got a simple set of pupusas - bean and cheese and spinach. They were hearty, greasy, and delicious and came with a side of cabbage slaw. Love the home made quality of the food. 

Thumbs up for the vegan menu items. Still, I can't echo the enthusiasm everyone else has for this place. Definitely good, but not great.
author: Clare B.

description: Literally one of my favorite restaurants. I've had nothing but good experiences and I love the area. I originally came here because Yelp helped me find vegan French toast. Turns out they also have vegan breakfast burritos, vegan tamales and vegan pupusas. I've brought a few people to eat here, all of which were non vegans, and everyone loved their food. It's a little under the radar but I enjoy the low key vibe and the friendly service. I very much recommend trying it out.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Good vegan options, decently priced, and reasonable sized portions. These three things made me very happy when I took my visiting friends here for breakfast. It's not easy to find good vegan breakfast options in SF, let alone on a weekday. But Sunrise had fresh, well-seasoned dishes that we all enjoyed. And better yet, we all felt like we had the perfect amount of food.

I'm excited to come back here and try out some of their other options.
author: Jon T.

description:
Decent place. Not outstanding. Liked that it had vegan choices on the menu and still was Latin American. 

I've never seen vegan pupusas before and they were quite good. I usually don't order pupusas anymore because of all the cheese so was happy to see a vegan version. 

My husband's tofu scramble (also vegan) was pretty standard. But again, nice to have that choice on the menu. 

Portions are a bit small for the price. But this is the Mission after all.
author: Nora S.

description:
When it comes to eating out, I am an extremely harsh critic. I love to cook and often feel like I can make things better at home. But not this time. 

Sun Rise is my new favorite hearty breakfast spot! Huevos con chorizo y platanos were delicious! Everything was perfect including the friendly and fast service. Salsa music plays in the background at just the right volume and the golden walls are warmly lit by the sun. Will definitely be back with friends in tow.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Good food! Cheap food! 

Yes, this place is a great find. Especially since they serve their mimosas in a big water glass and not in your typical flute glass. I have to say for $6 bucks, I scored big with this one item alone! I ordered the Huevos Revueltos con Jamon which came with hand made tortillas. Gotta love that it's hand made. We also got plantains which you can never go wrong with and my friend had vegetarian tamale which was really delicious. 

The place is a bit small so be prepared because when we went it was busy. They had nice decorations and a purple christmas tree which i loved. The service could pick up a bit especially since the place is small so two servers should be good. We had to ask for water and cream but the ladies were friendly.
author: Zara-Maria S.

description:
Everyone was really friendly and the food was great. The eggs Benedict, pancake combo and French toast were all very good. 
The sunrise eggs were good but it has way too much spinach.
The breakfast burrito was probably my favorite. 
Definitely get the papusas! The pork ones were very good. 

It's a nice atmosphere but it was a little slow and you can only split the bill with 2 cards. Great Sunday funday brunch place where you don't have to wait for a table.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Love this place, best huevos rancheros in the Mission hands down, and I love how this place is run by women. You can taste the love and care in every bite.  
The prices are great,  the music unobtrusive and the walls are decorated in an interesting assortment of art pieces. They don't skimp you on the mimosa either, each one is served in a pint! Brunch lovers dream almost any day of the week all day long. 

They also have great pupusas!
author: Caitlin S.

description:
Breakfast was totally on point .Came in today on a busy Sunday morning to give this place a try.

The service was pretty slow since there understaffed, which my friend and I waited for 15 minutes for our food to arrived. 

I ordered the eggs benedict with home fries and two slices of oranges and apple, which it's a pretty good portion size but man, it got me full after eating the whole plate.Cooked to perfection that will make my stomach full.

Despite the long wait, this is a go to place for breakfast and brunch on a good price.
author: Cindy G.

description:
If you're in the Mission, you MUST try this place. After one visit, I am incredibly enamored with everything about it.

I tried the vegan zucchini pupusa and a side of plantains. They were both incredible! The plantains were so so SO yummy! I could have chowed down on at least one or two more sides of these sweet babies, but I showed some will power and stopped myself. 

I also brought home a breakfast burrito for a loved one and was able to sample some of it. The spicy salsa was excellent, and the burrito is a pretty large sucker for only $6.50. I imagine that this burrito could only be enhanced by a cold beer on the side, but I have to work tomorrow morning, so drinking is not an option tonight. 

I'm so incredibly grateful that they have plenty of vegan options that are clearly marked as such. Yay, Sun Rise! You're doing it right. 

The lady working tonight was so lovely and sweet. She seemed a little quiet and/or shy. Perhaps I should have broken out what little Spanish I know, just to break the ice. Would that make things more awkward? I never know what the proper etiquette is. 

It's also SO affordable. We ordered a bunch of snacks and the bill was just over $20. Very reasonable! 

I'm tempted to return sometime this weekend to try their breakfast items, like vegan French toast. Sounds fan-freaking-tastic!
author: Brandi W.

description: Service was terrible, chilequiles were soggy and bland, sour cream had turned, and they screwed up our order. I have no idea how this place is so highly rated.
author: Carla C.

description: One time I found a screw in my food and never came back after that. Luckily I noticed it before I had taken a bite!
author: Amanda M.

description: This is where I go for a solid breakfast. The huevos al gusto is both hearty and moderately priced. The women who work here are always friendly and hard-working.
author: Jolly G.

description: Best vegan soyrizo I've ever had! Way better than St. Francis down the street. I also ordered the vegan papusa and it was amazing. Super authentic, tasty, fresh food. It's so nice they have vegan options. I lived in the neighborhood for 6 years and walked by this place a million times but never ate here until today. I will definitely b back.
author: Amy P.

description: It's a cozy family restaurant. We were there for brunch we were concerned about the noisy crowd (see pic) in it. The noise was overwhelming! A few customers also seemed annoyed, but no one said anything. A huge relief came when the crowd left the restaurant. In general, the food was okay. It's easy to tell from the portion and menu that the restaurant caters to a specific kind of clientele. But the close proximity between customers makes any loud noise unbearable...If it is going to be that kind of noisy crowd, I won't eat there.
author: K T.

description:
Came in for a quick bite to eat.   I ordered an egg dish and a flat rice tortilla.  I waited 40 minutes  for the egg dish which I couldn't find because the dish had a bunch of soggy chips covering a dollop of meat and sauce.  The rice paddy was charred on the bottom, and had that carcinogenic burnt taste. The meat filling again was measly in portion.

AFTER the long wait I was disappointed at the food, but the service was a joke.  I asked for water and was never served.  How cheap is that.
One of the worst dining experiences I've had ever.
author: Tiki D.

description:
This place is small, but does have quite a bit of tables inside and 2 tables on the outside. I came here on a Saturday morning at around 11am and it was full! But only waited about 5 min for a seat! 

My friend and i ordered:

Papusas (one spinach, one zucchini) with cheese: BOMB! I love the cabbage slaw it comes with and the tomato salsa!!! So light and refreshing!

Chilaquiles: It was pretty good, but still doesnt compare to the chilaquiles I've had in Mexico! This one was more chippy, the chips were crunchy. Lots of sauce. Chorizo and egg was too crumbled. Felt like I was eating soggy chips and salsa but the taste was very good. Still better than any other restaurant I have had chilaquiles in the States!

Breakfast platter with beans, avocado, eggs, and fresh tortilla. SO GOOD!
author: Annie K.

description:
We tried this place for breakfast.  The restaurant was nearly empty so we were seated immediately by a very nice server.
My partner had a ham omelet with hash browns and cranberry juice while I had chorizo scrambled with eggs and black beans.  My dish came with three small corn tortillas and little containers of salsa and sour cream.  There was also a slice of nice queso on my plate.
I liked my meal very much.  The chorizo was not oily and very tasty.  The black beans, tortillas and queso were fine.
My partner said his meal was okay but nothing special.
One small disappointment - I wanted decaf coffee but all they had was decaf expresso.  So I had a glass of milk.
The food is pretty good, the service was excellent and the restaurant was clean and comfortable.  We might try this place for lunch or dinner.
author: Philip C.

description: Amazing food. First time having vegan French toast after 7 years of being vegan. The vegan breakfast burrito was by far my favorite item on the menu. Best soy chorizo I've had anywhere! The service is very friendly and the atmosphere is casual. We came towards the end of brunch on Sunday around 2pm and it wasn't too busy although I've heard it is earlier in the day. Good for smaller groups 2-4 ppl.
author: John P.

description:
So so so delicious and an amazing value!

The revueltas pupusas are perfect with the cabbage slaw and spicy red sauce, and the platanos with black beans and crema were the perfect side for it.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
It was warmer outside than it was in my dark Victorian bedroom, but it was so cold in the latter that, on trying to wake and start my day, I instead burrowed back into bed and turned on the electric blanket, fearing the chill of the unwarmed bra, wondering if I could fashion a tracksuit from the blanket itself. 

Thus ensconced, I spent hours tweeting across time zones about a short-lived British show called Sex Box, in which a hapless couple does it in a sealed box on a sound stage while a team of sex pundits discusses their relationship before they emerge, satiated or not, to be quizzed about their intimate feelings about their intimate feelings, the idea being they'll be primed toward honesty and insight by their temporal proximity to carnality. Apparently it flopped. Apparently a version is coming stateside anyway. 

The takes & jokes & quips tapered off, and I realized I hadn't eaten. An image sprang forth in my mind, so vivid I could have practically snatched it out of the air and tucked into it with an ethereal knife and fork and been corporally fed with real caloric sustenance. 

I threw on an array of clothes from the cleanish pile near the laundry hamper and hustled myself over to Sun Rise Café, a treasure I hope remains untouched for as long as I am ambulatory and sentient in San Francisco. 

I took a seat at the window. The sun came through the window and lit my copy of Harper's. The waitress remembered me although it had been several months since I met a series of first dates here for brunch on an OkCupid spree. 

After a cursory glance at the menu, I ordered the Sun Rise Eggs, which after a short enough time emerged from the kitchen on a winged platter borne by a cloud emitting internal, gold-blue light. 

Sun Rise Eggs are the house take on eggs Benedict, the English muffin topped with bacon, spinach, avocado and a poached egg. The egg, my God. It's as if they carefully scooped a slotted spoon into a classic cookbook and retrieved the poached egg attempted by students for centuries, and placed it upon the aforementioned delectations arrayed atop the English muffin. Perfect in form, exploding from the fork's touch onto the tower of luscious food, the egg beheld itself, and it was good. 

Sun Rise's house potatoes are similarly the pinnacle of house potatoes, each bite-sized chunk perfectly crisp, but not dark, seasoned just so, and as fluffy inside as a mashed angel. 

I ordered a side of black beans to dip the potatoes into. This was my wisest choice in decades. 

The coffee is fine. The walls are cheery. Everything in the world is more sublime now that my belly is full of Sun Rise Eggs. 

Four stars, because 2 slices of apple and a wedge of orange is hardly "served with fruit," and the waitress, though otherwise excellent, does not visit the table to ask if everything is all right.
author: Tarin T.

description: The food is delicious, affordable and the music and atmosphere is authentic Mexican. They offer Vegan options and the waitress is nice. Food came out quickly.
author: Margaret P.

description: My husband and I have been going for 5 years and it's our "go to" breakfast joint! The food is delicious. My son loves their beans. The service is great too. Five stars for sure. I'm happy to know it's also a Family owned business
author: Gloria N.

description: Went for breakfast here after looking at some of the trendy well reviewed offerings in the neighborhood. Happy I made the visit. Coffee was strong and delicious. Vegan food was fast and yummy.  Server was sweet. Place was quiet. Hipsters should take their heads out of their truffle infused butts to check this local spot out.
author: Vittorio A.

description: Really tasty food - everything delicious  but especially breakfast, platanos frijoles & cream, and of course pupusas. Good value. Sweet owner that supports community, neighborhood artists & social justice movements. Good longtime community place to spend money if you're gonna go out to eat on 24th. They are a small place so if they're busy and you're in a big hurry maybe not the best time to come, although once my boo needed to get to work & we told them & they were awesome about speeding things up. Overall highly recommended.
author: Carrie S.

description: Sun Rise is the best. The women that work there are so nice and honestly are one of the main reasons I go. I just moved to LA and I am sad that I don't have Sun Rise anymore :(
author: Allie M.

description:
Cheap brunch place in the Mission, but really nothing that special. You can get an eggs Benedict for $10 where other places might charge like $13/14, but everything is pretty standard.  I got the sun rise eggs, which include poached eggs, spinach, avocado, and bacon on an English muffin. Plus potatoes and like 2 slices of fruit. I wasn't blown away by any means and the portion of bacon/spinach was kind of sparse, but it satisfied. The poached eggs were done very well, too - perfectly round and runny. 

So basically, food is cheap but portions can be smaller than usual, but it offers many different, non-standard brunch options (I just didn't try them). The store itself is quite small and pretty stuffy, but with character. Oh, and an unrelated tip: check out the little bakery next to this place for an after-brunch dessert - 65c pastries of all types that are baked fresh in the mornings!
author: Cissy C.

description: This is my favorite spot in the whole Bay Area for vegan breakfast. I recommended the pupusas, always. They're amazing. Order your hash browns extra crispy. And the soyrizo is AMAZING. Yay everything!
author: Anna T.

description:
First off I just want to thank Yelp for existing because if it weren't for Yelp I wouldn't have had such a wonderful experience here. 

I am from LA and was visiting family in San Francisco. On our last day we wanted to have a good breakfast for our long journey home. Being Salvadorian my parents wanted to have the typical Hispanic breakfast eggs, beans, cheese, and all that good stuff. Thank god I was able to find Sun Rise on Yelp. 

Their place was small, nice and cozy. Their service was a bit slow but then again it was a Sunday morning and only one waiter. But from the beginning the service was excellent. The waiter being Hispanic herself and most of the people eating there were white she made my parents and family members feel comfortable by speaking Spanish to them. 

All of us were satisfied with our meals. I ordered huevos con chorizo and a side of platanos and it was delicious!!  My mom ordered a mushroom omelet which was also very good. We also ordered a quesadilla, a salvadorian sweet bread which had a different taste to it then a typical quesadilla but was still really good. 

Overall my family and I enjoyed our meal and I would highly recommend this place to anyone looking for an authentic central American meal!
author: Nidia E.

description: Came here for dinner on a Sunday night, we were the only people!! But we were pretty determined to get breakfast food that night so we tried it anyway. We're not quitters. Chilaquiles was delicious! Never had anything remotely like it :) but even tho we were the only table in the restaurant, our server took a while to come take our order (probably forgot about us), and our food took a while.. I do recommend the food tho!
author: Katie S.

description:
Food is wonderful, service is excellent. I have taken so many friends there because I know they will love the food. Prices are great and portions are large.
Guadalupe Amador
author: Gusdalupe A.

description:
Great place for those generous Latin platos that you crave. 

Found Sun Rise on Yelp, around the corner from my boyfriend's. No food in the house and I was starving and needed to have a good meal before I headed out for a four-hour training (no lunch break).  I'm vegan-ish and was pleasantly surprised to see that the menu has vegan options. 

I had the Vegan Chorizo plato - soy chorizo, beans, rice, nice warm corn tortillas, and salsa. It was simple, delicious, and generously portioned for under $10. It was more than I would normally eat but I chowed it down and kept me fueled from 10:30 am until dinner! 

Service was prompt and friendly. Plain but cozy decor. Neither crowded nor empty. Food came out in a timely manner. I would come again, perhaps with the boy or friends.
author: Jung F.

description:
What a great find! 

We were visiting SF and as a vegan, I'm always looking out for great vegan/vegetarian spots to eat. Not only did finding this place give me some exposure to the very awesome Mission area, I also got to eat some truly delicious food.

There is a very authentic feel about this place and our waitress was lovely, informative and although there may have been a slight language barrier; we got everything delivered to us beautifully.

The food was delicious and reminiscent of something you'd find in a regular Mexican household. I had the vegan burrito and it was full of flavour and spices - unlike anything I'd eaten before.

Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area.
author: Evan K.

description:
My girl and I breakfasted here for it's vegan options.  She'd heard about the vegan French toast in particular.
We each ordered a mocha with a shot of espresso and it was made to perfection.  Never had a better mocha.  She was all about it at first but said it was too sweet later.
For eats we got the French Toast and the breakfast burrito (both vegan).
The french toast wasn't the best *looking* french toast in the world but tasted as good as any I've ever had.  Served with little bits of bananas, clementines, apples and strawberries not to mention some quality syrup.  Brown sugar at the table too!
The breakfast burrito was stupendous.  I never had soyrizo before but this was better than any chorizo I had before my conversion.  Just the right mix of flavors, avocados black beans etc.  Nice salsa too.

Beyond that it's a nicely put together place and not busy at all for lunch on a weekday.
Will certainly return, many times.
author: Milo I.

description:
Found this little restaurant after a rough night and a subsequent search for some mazda wheels the next morning caused by a run in with a curb...

This place turned out to be a pleasant surprise and I've been back several times since then!

Great food and great ambiance.  There's all sorts of nifty paintings and sculptures and stuff on the walls and the restaurant has a great airy feel.  Makes me feel like I'm eating in South America.

Heuvos Al Gusto.  2 eggs, rice and beans, and some fried plantains.  Simple but delicious.

Pupusas are delicious as well, stuffed full of cheese.   You ever see on TV when someone pulls a slice of pizza up and all the cheese forms strings? Yeah same thing here.

If you're in the mission and aren't in the mood for mexican, this is the place to go.
author: Tu T.

description:
I love this place because its never crowded and the service and food are excellent. I always get the Huevos Rancheros and its no surprise that the cook knocks it out of the park. These are really nice people that serve great food with no attitude.  

TOP SECRET TIP. The burritos are huge, delicious and the least expensive breakfast item.
author: Joseph M.

description: Five stars for the vegan French toast...three for my husband's unimpressive meal.  The vegan French toast was so incredible I actually had to make sure it was vegan!  So grateful for the many vegan options and nice service.  Sorry the picture posted I already ate the yummy fresh fruit off the top of the French toast.
author: Vivienne V.

description: Living in NY by way of Texas, I don't often get to enjoy chorizo and black beans and homemade tortillas, which made this quite the treat! Get the soyrizo - even if you're not a vegan, it's delicious! Can't wait to visit SF again and have breakfast here!
author: Sydney K.

description:
Sun Rise has fallen far from it's former glory. They used to be excellently-priced Mexican/American fare with ok coffee and decent food. 

We had some funky orders (substitutions, vegetarian, nothing super complicated) and it just looked like the cook was having a really bad day. The one with substitutions came out in a pile, and the vegetarian eggs benedict was covered in bacon. Our friend asked for a new one, and they simply removed the bacon. 

The good: it is cheap, this is true.
The bad: food is meh.
author: Amanda B.

description:
The muy authentico Central American B-Fast!  

Beans,...perfect.  Hot, fresh tortillas? Yes please. One of the best chicken tamales I've ever had. Oh, those tamales are only $2.50!

My girl had ye olde huevos rancheros and the eggs were cooked perfectly. 

I would definitely come back here for my farmer cheese, eggs with ham and black bean fix anytime.  Just like my fantasy Honduran Mom down south makes.
author: Dusty B.

description: Cutely designed! And the food is super amazing! Very homey, and the staffs are such gems from South America - they serve you with their hearts and smiles.
author: Yany W.

description: WOWOOWOWOWOWIWOW!!! Was looking for a quick breakfast and I stumbled onto s treasure. Affordable, authentic as hell and delicious. Great service and nice place, reminds me of the Yucatan peninsula. Check this place out, do not miss!
author: Alma A.

description:
The lady serving the restaurant is seriously so sweet. She has one of those genuinely happy & caring demeanors that reminds you of your favorite grandma and just makes you want to hug her.

That and an entire meal for $11 including tax/tip! This was with half the table getting beers too - we just split it evenly so I probably even overpaid a little.

I tried:

* Pork & cheese and spinach & cheese pupusas (corn) - 4 stars
Their pupusas overall are good! Both sides have a nice crisp to it, burnt just barely enough to get that slight browning without going overboard. There is a decent amount of filling - and the pork was pretty good. I'm not sure if I tasted the spinach (though later I asked for beans in there as well and she may have thought I wanted to replace spinach with beans).

* Huevo con chorizo - 4 stars
Pretty dang good as well. I like that all their brunch options are available at dinner! The beans were a tiny tiny bit starchy, but overall really delicious.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Given the slow service and weak food, I was pretty surprised Sun Rise had such a high rating. Two simple dishes, poached eggs and a salad, took over 30 minutes. Then the salad had a hair in it, and the poached eggs were well overcooked. I don't plan on coming back.
author: Ben W.

description:
Sun Rise is another denizen of 24th Street that favorably contributes to the seemingly endless array of dining options in the area.

Although I am usually not a fan of sweet & salty meals (Hawaiian pizza and pineapple fried rice come to mind), Sun Rise's Huevos Al Gusto with plantains has begun to gnaw on my stance.  

The Al Gusto's plantains are perfectly cooked, tender to the bite and not mushy from overripeness  - each of the 3 pieces lends a natural, sticky sweetness that does not overpower the other flavors.  The over easy eggs are solid enough to be transported into a fresh tortilla, where it can then be broken for the yolk to trickle throughout the self-made taco; the slab of crumbly homemade cheese is subtly yet powerfully salty; the plentiful black bean & rice mixture provides a gluing foundation that holds the other fillings together; and the slightly spicy salsa only enhances its companion ingredients.

Be sure to pack each tortilla to capacity, since the filling to tortilla ratio is overwhelmingly in favor of the fillings.  Paired with a refreshing, simple iced coffee, the Al Gusto makes for a rather satisfying lunch.

Note: Minimum charge of $10 to use credit cards

Will be back for more!
author: Andrew M.

description:
This place gets the job done, no complaints.  Prices are cheap, and the food is pretty good.  

The typical breakfast stuff (eggs, toast, bacon) is standard diner quality...nothing to write home about, but fills you up nicely.  However, their Latin dishes are more flavorful and interesting.
author: Heidi S.

description: Frickin' delicious breakfast. I had huevos al gusto. How to they pack all that flavor into rice and beans? Insane. Good coffee too.
author: Arthur G.

description: Good for breakfast and portion size hits the spot, enough to hold me until around 1, 2pm.  Their breakfast burrito was delicious and recommend others to try their other Latin dishes.
author: Jessica S.

description:
This place is yummy for your tummy! Very nice and smiley staff. Food is amazing. I usually get the breakfast burrito and for the price, its fantastic. Great way to start any part of your day.

 The cheese and zucchini pupusa  is amazingly refreshing. Yea that's right, its refreshing. Something about it when you put the moist cheesy hand made corn tortilla in your mouth that it just slips around on your tongue and when you chew it, a burst of soft cheese flavor explodes your taste buds. When your ready to swallow after all the excitement, you get this freshness feeling down your throat to your stomach. You WILL say, "mmmm".  I recommend the pupusa, with or without the zucchini.
author: Chris L.

description: I went with two of my friends last night for dinner around 7pm. There was one other person dining when we arrived, otherwise it was super quiet for a Saturday night. We asked to have some music turned on and our server put on some tunes and then came over and walked us through some recommendations. She was super sweet, genuine, and made us feel at home. I ordered a couple of papusas and fried plantains and my friends got the típicos salvadoreños, which was pictured on the front of the menu. The food really hit the spot and I would absolutely go again. It's not hip, but I'd rather eat something delicious in a place that feels comfy and homey than somewhere modern where they miss the mark on food.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Get the huevos al gusto (which is gluten-free) if you like eating eggs, or they have a bunch of vegan choices if you don't. 

Stick with the Salvadoran food selections! 

The maize/corn pupusas here are gluten free too (unlike many other places in The Mission that add wheat flour to the corn mixture) and include flavors zucchini, loroco, bean, spinach, various meat options and any of which can come with beans or cheese inside.

The food is always good and easy to spend $10 or less on a decent meal.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Came to this place to try out the vegan fare.  They had a surprising number of options, Vegan French Toast, Vegan Breakfast Burrito, vegan soy chorizo, vegan pupusas, and perhaps 1 or 2 others.  I ordered the Vegan French Toast, and spinach vegan pupusas.  They weren't necessarily bad, but I definitely wouldn't say they were good either.  Everything tasted quite bland.

I actually live 2 blocks from this place, and even with that convenience, I don't think I'd come again unless I really need to.  I'd rather walk about 7-8 blocks to the Herbivore grill (which interestingly has a lower rating).  Mission Pie is nearby for some great vegan fare too.  There are just better vegan options in the Mission.
author: Matt T.

description: Sunrise has an awesome breakfast at a great price. Would highly recommend the breakfast burrito - there was a plethora of bacon inside!
author: Abby B.

description:
Despite the slow pace of service I appreciate that Sunrise has so many vegan options.  I have been a few times and have come to love the breakfast burrito.  It is filling and stuffed with vegan soyrizo and potatoes.  The vegan spinach pupusa is good and it is fun (as a vegan) to enjoy a culturally specific, Salvadorean, dish.  

I only gave 3 stars due to the chronically slow service and low quality sides.  I have been unimpressed with the home fries and hashbrowns, and the tofu dishes leave a lot to be desired.  

The price is a good value for the amount of food you get and I will continue to go when I have some extra time to wait for the check.
author: Jason C.

description: Solid place, but since we didn't try any off the vegan options that everyone's raving about, maybe we missed their specialty... The food was pretty decent (spinach omelette and breakfast burrito), and the coffee was ok. Nice little place, but by the sounds of the other reviews I think I'd probably try the veggie / vegan options next time...
author: Kiera S.

description:
I usually run in here for takeout Pupusas and Tamales. If you call ahead, it usually only takes them 15 minutes to cook and it's good snack on the way to the 24th Street BART. 

The Mixed  Pupusa (Beans, Cheese and Pork) is by far my favorite, the Pork Pupusa is fairly dry in my experience. The tamale was good, but be prepared for a lot of oil. My advice is to ask for a handful of napkins, they won't put any in the bag . The prices are what you'd expect in the Mission. 

I plan on coming back for a sit down breakfast in the future. Sun Rise seems pretty full on the weekend for breakfast which seems like a sign of good things.
author: Jake B.

description:
I have stumbled upon this cute little neighborhood restaurant and now have eaten here a few times. The lady, presumably the owner, always greets me with a smile. She is the sunshine of the place.

On the few occasions I have Huevos Al Gusto, fried eggs over hard and scrambled. The sumptuous breakfast comes with choice of avocado or plantain, and I opted the latter. The beans and rice are cooked together to a stew of perfect flavor. I also like the three corn tortillas that come steamy hot in foil.

The restaurant is very clean and tranquil. Pieces of arts decorate the yellow wall. Breakfast with bottomless coffee $10. I'll be back for sure--to try other Latin-style breakfast plates and the pupusas.
author: Matt Y.

description: Vegan Popusa  are very delicious and vegan chorizo , vegan French toast are amazing !!!!!!!!!!!
author: Juan D.

description: Don't know where the family is actually from, but the entire breakfast experience reminded me of Guatemala and I loved it! The lady was so nice and patient as I tried to communicate and have a conversation with her in my horribly broken Spanish. and the food was great. homemade, and hit the spot. Definitely a place to frequent.
author: Zara S.

description:
I feel deceived by yelp. I have no idea how this place got 4 stars.

Came here w 2 girlfriends before a bread making class at La Victoria on a Sunday late morning. Did not get greeted even the waitress saw us. Took a long time to get seated, get our drinks and orders. On top of the bad service. The food was mediocre. I had the spinach scramble which was indicated as a new menu item. The portion was puny, the presentation unappetizing (the eggs in the scramble looked hella "grainy") and the hash browns slimy. Plus the menu said it comes w home fries, not hash browns. My girlfriends' one lets looked much more appetizing but they said the taste was mediocre too. Maybe we should've stuck w the Latino themed dishes.
author: Jenny C.

description: My dinner was awful!! Bad chicken, in-ripe tomatoes, terrible white rice (was expecting some good authentic Hispanic rice). Will not be going back.
author: Marie S.

description:
Lovely chefs, delightful clean space and really, really good Mexican food. You cannot go wrong here people. Many vegan choices, they really cater to the customer.
My buddy had the chiliquiles and I had the spinach scramble, both delicious. Just right portions and a sweet staff.
We'll be back.,
author: Natasha Z.

description: Wow this place is so delicious, I wish they had a location closer to home. Amazing food - great quality, VERY fresh, and they don't douse their food with oil (because they don't need to, with all the natural flavors from the spices they use). We were so pleased with the vegan options!! It's hard to find decent vegan options (that actually taste good), but Sunrise did not disappoint! The vegan breakfast burrito is so good, I'm still thinking about it. Also, it is VERY authentic latin food, so even non vegans will be pleased, I'm sure. One last thing-- some people mentioned that the prices are high.... I completely disagree. I feel that they are fair for the quality of the food you get. We got 2 meals, 2 sides, 3 beverages for about $40.
author: Lexi T.

description:
This has become my favorite breakfast burrito in the city. It's kinda phenomenal!  Eggs, fried potatoe, cheese and either bacon or chorizo. The chorizo isn't the greasy ground up stuff fom most places, it's a large sausage split in two and perfectly fried. That said, there's still a bit of grease - go for bacon if you wanna stay on the drier side. 

Otherwise, aide from the burrito, I go for the plantains, the mimosa, and the warm atmosphere.
author: Ivan L.

description: One of my favorite spots on 24 st. I am a fan of any business that supports social justice causes and this place is amazing!Also the food is great!! Tamales and pupusas are under $10!
author: Adriana M.

description: Amazing amazing brunch! Had amazing eggs Benedict with salmon and Plantains. I defiantly recommend
author: Mitch A.

description: Keep going back and finding the same great food. Really enjoy this place, has good Latin and "America" breakfast options. I especially love that they have good vegan options. I hope this place continues to be a part of the neighborhood.
author: Steven B.

description: This place is pretty good. Service is friendly but not fast. Food is pretty standard cafe food. I got an omelet which took a little while to get here but was piping hot and fresh. Coffee tasted a bit burnt but was quickly refilled after I finished it.
author: Andrew S.

description:
You know that scene at the end of Goodfellas when he is living in the suburbs in witness protection and complains that he ordered spaghetti and got egg noodles and ketchup? That is what the chilequiles are like here :( Soggy chips with what seems to be pureed tomato sauce. No flavor at all. 

I poked around and took few bites but it was so unappealing that I just gave up and then went to San Jalisco for delicious chilequiles :)

The pupusa was okay so I am giving them two stars instead of one.
author: lisa g.

description:
Great find! Came here with the wife after her graveyard shift and had a quick brunch. Didn't really know what to expect (and didn't know so much about the vegan options until browsing the reviews after our visit), but was surprised nonetheless. Had myself a chorizo scramble. It tasted great, rich flavors, a wonderful, dirty red ripe with flavor. And filling too. My wife had corned beef hash, which was equally crusted with sear. Nom.

There was something else about this place that was just a little magical. The lady behind the counter was really nice. And even some of the people walking in and out would say "Good morning." In a city where people often go from point A to point B with their horseblinds on or spend 80 plus minutes waiting for the trendiest brunch spots in the city, it's nice to find a quite eatery that's a respite from both.

Vegan or not, I look forward to coming back and trying few other things on the menu.
author: Tony L.

description: This hidden gem has authentic central American food with plenty of vegan and vegetarian options with a quaint, non-scene vibe and super-reasonable prices. Food is served by lovely and sweet Latin American women and you hear as much Spanish as English here. It feels like you're in the Mission of 20 years ago. Highly recommended.
author: Brian K.

description:
Loved it for one big reason: It reminded me of home and mom's saturday/sunday morning breakfasts :)  I got Huevas al Gusto which came with two eggs, rice/black beans (we call this casamiento), plantains or avocado, sour cream, and salsa.  I also ordered a coffee and a chicken tamale.  The food was just like mom's, which I loved. 

My only issue was the service: very, very slow.  Not on the kitchen end but it looked like there really should have been another worker (either taking orders or working on coffee).  Also, the coffee isn't particularly good. 

I'm eager to go back and try their pupusas.  Beware tho, they say that their tamales pisques are vegan but usually the masa used to make the tamales has chicken stock in it.
author: Banana S.

description: We ordered eggs dutchess , chilaquiles and granola with fruit and yogurt. All three things were yummy :) service is excellent and before I forget try the quesadilla pastry with hot chocolate! Heaven! Total bill $30 so not so expensive.Will be back.
author: Rishabh J.

description:
I love the crap out of this place. It's little and tucked under an unassuming sign on 24th St. The only time I've ever managed to make it here is around noon on Saturday or Sunday, post-hangover/pre-drinking. It never fails to deliver. I'm always 100 percent better when I leave than when I arrived. That's not to say I'm 100 percent, but hey, I'm not expecting miracles. 

They have a monster of a breakfast burrito for 5 dollars. Five dollars! And it taste good, too. I almost always opt for the huevos rancheros, though. It cost, like, 7 bucks. Well worth the price. Two people can eat like kings here for less than 20 dollars, and the food is awesome. If you live in the area and you aren't already coming here, there is probably something wrong with your brain. I don't mind though. It makes is easier for me to get a seat when it's packed. Which, at the time of day I've managed to make it here, is always.
author: Elias A.

description:
I live too close to this place- The reason why I come back is because of the warmth and home-like feel of this restaurant. From the dining room decor, to the people that work there, and to the food. 
It feels like I'm in someones home. They make you feel warm and fuzzy. Food is delicious and the options are great.
author: Mario M.

description: Opened late for breakfast but food was really good.  Nice menu selection.  Good fresh ingredients.
author: Joel V.

description: REALLY yummy vegan options (we had the spinach pupusa, vegan french toast, and vegan breakfast burrito!), warm atmosphere, + welcoming & friendly service!
author: Zo T.

description:
Love this place! The breakfast is my favorite, especially the huevos al gusto. The rice and beans will melt in your mouth.

Writing an update. I come here now weekly to treat myself to a good, Latin breakfast. The pancakes are some of the best I've had in the city - try the ones with strawberries, they sautee them so the berries are nice and warm! The pupusas are also very good. And you really can't beat any of the breakfast items

Great assortment of vegetarian and vegan options - plus it's really inexpensive.
author: Priscilla M.

description: I tried this for the first time this week after reading lots of good reviews. I ordered the vegan breakfast burrito and liked it- but wasn't blown away. Perhaps next time I will try the pupusa or plantains. There wasn't much service- our coffee was never refilled, and I had to get up and go ask the server to pour out my cold coffee so I could refill my cup. It's definitely a no frills place but I would definitely give it another try though.
author: Sky B.

description: yum. yum. yum. chilaquiles are super tasty here. tamales, delicious and filling. order these two, and you're set to go!
author: Marlene T.

description: This place is amazing!!!!!!!! Vegan pupusas. So many vegan/vegetarian options and the food is delicious and authentic. Yes yes yes!
author: Raquel M.

description: Very cleanly prepared food in a home style way.  I like the various egg options along with the white cheese and avocado on the side.  Beans, rice and plantains are good too.  The Papusas are not very good and there are much better places in the neighborhood for those.   Service is "home style" too so if you are in a hurry or expecting formality, this isn't the best place.  I find I usually have to get up and go to the counter in order to pay my bill.
author: Neal M.

description:
On our quest to try new restaurants, this morning we had breakfast at Sun Rise Restaurant. Arriving before 11am, we found a parking spot right in front AND there was no wait for a table. Half an hour later, there was a line out the door!

I had scrambled eggs, pancakes and bacon. One friend had vegan breakfast with "vegan chorizo," and commented that the hot sauce that came with it could have killed her. Our other person had tofu with pesto, and a bagel with cream cheese. This place has something for everyone! Prices are very low and portions are small, so if you want the "lumberjack breakfast," go somewhere else. 

Only two servers, but they were fast enough before the place got too crowded, and the food was quite good. Tables and floor were very clean!

It was noisy, and there was a football game on the TV.
author: Gretchen B.

description:
I came here for breakfast and really enjoyed it.  It was about 8am on a Saturday and we had the place to ourselves for the first little bit.  Sooooo nice and tranquil compared to the hustle and bustle of some of the breakfast places in the city.
