I was really impressed by all the vegan options, but was craving a salad (I know, I eat salads for breakfast :oP)  So that's what I got!  

Basic Salad:  was pretty much exactly as described, a nice basic salad.  It came with a TON of walnuts though, about a full cup, YUM.

Side of Platanos, frijoles negros:  A side of plaintains and beans.   This were both very simple and very good.  I mixed the plaintains with the walnuts from my salad.  Sooooo yuuuum.

The owner?/chef was this really sweet lady.  I ordered a decaf coffee and they didn't have a pot brewed so she brought out an Americano.  I asked for two refills and it was no problem at all and no extra charge.
author: Evelyn N.

description:
I was out in the Mission with a friend after a rough day.  We had a craving for some breakfast food and stumbled upon this little place.  I had the Sun Rise eggs, and they were absolutely perfectly done.  Hot and nice and gooey on the inside, making that first cut into the egg a really happy experience.  The orange juice was freshly squeezed, and the coffee was pretty decent.  I have no idea where they get their jam, but it was addictive and had me keep eating the toast even when I was full.

The only thing that was disappointing to me were the sides.  The potatoes were really bland and the fruit was somewhat browned.  My sides were also given in really small portions, compared to the nice big couple of eggs I was given.  It would have been nice to have freshly cut fruit.

Overall, this was a great cheap breakfast place.
author: Joanna S.

description: This place is tasty, cheap, fast, and the women who work here are the sweetest!! Come in for some delicious pupusas and friendly faces.
author: Eliza D.

description: Officially my favorite place to eat in San Francisco! Although SF is pretty vegan friendly as it is, Sun Rise is a gem to me.  The service was amazing and the servers themselves were so friendly, that it definitely felt more like I was over at a friend's house for lunch, which is something not many places can achieve.  The food was so good, it's ridiculous.  I ordered a vegan breakfast burrito, and it was possibly the greatest thing I've ever had the privilege and blessing to consume.  My friend ordered a vegan tamale, which was just as good! You really can't go wrong with their Menu, there's something for everyone :)
author: Angela M.

description: Been here a few times with friends and family. The vegan pupusas are off the chain! And they have great, big mimosas for a good price too. I usually get the pupusa plate with rice and beans and the coleslaw (amazing) and it's only $7-$8 and totally fills you up.
author: Anna M.

description:
One word: PERFECTION.

My husband and I were recently in SF and had brunch at Sun Rise one morning.  I had the vegan breakfast burrito with soyrizo and it was easily the best breakfast burrito I have ever had that didn't come out of my own kitchen.  It's insanely cheap at $6.50 for a massive burrito.  I also had a mimosa as big as my head that was also very low priced.  My husband had an egg dish that he also enjoyed.  The space is really casual, warm and inviting and the service could not possibly be friendlier.  If I lived in SF, I would be brunching here at least once a week.  What a little gem of a restaurant.
author: Tara J.

description:
We went here for breakfast on our way out of San Francisco. We were suprised when we pulled up that they serve vegan food, but gave it a try! Man were we happy we did. 

We order the vegan breakfast burrito, vegan french toast, and a vegan tamale. All 3 were great!! It was pretty cheap too compared to what we had been paying for vegan food all weekend. It was $20 for entire meal, and we both got drinks. The staff was really friendly, and service was quick.
author: Kim D.

description:
I found Sun Rise after finding our normal restaurant for pupusas (Santaneca by the BART station) was closed for Wednesdays.  The pupusas here are good and cheap.  Lots of flavor options -- though the revueltas (beans/pork/cheese) proportion was a little off -- most of which were pretty satisfying.

We did have a few stomach issues afterwards that I'm not sure were attributed to Sun Rise, but until then this is an adequate solution to your Central American cuisine cravings.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
It was going to be a tough day filled with a massages, Red Bulls, and trip to Monterey.

It had to start right. So I had the breakfast burrito and Horchata. 

Very fast service & friendly. The burrito was filling and delicious. The drink was cool and rehydrating.  Enjoy.
author: Sam K.

description: The nicest staff and a solid breakfast burrito. Exactly what I was looking for after a long night out. Burrito and coffee for $10.
author: Anand J.

description: My husband and I are vegans and we had plaintains, hash browns, pupusas and vegan chorizo. The food was average, but we couldn't enjoy it because of the ambience. Flies over the food and the wait time was long
author: Sri S.

description: The breakfast here is outstanding! We had the huevos al gusto-- poached eggs were perfectly cooked! The loroco & bean pupusa was also delicious.
author: Erin C.

description: Hands down THE BEST vegan burrito I've ever had in life! The coffee was on point as well. I'm so glad I found this cute, family owned restaurant. I was there first customer this morning and they treated me so well. What an awesome find! I can't wait to come back.
author: Bailey S.

description: A 5 star rating may seem a little overboard for this place, but the reason it deserves 5 stars is because this spot is exactly what I want it to be. I get the Huevos Al Gusto with plantains pretty much every time. This place is just so comforting to me. Every meal is equivalent to a hug from your grandmother. Coffee is good too (Philz is across the street so I guess you could go there and get better coffee if you don't like the coffee they have here). Hands down one of my favorite breakfast spots in SF for something cheap, consistent, and solid. Screw Flanders.
author: Eucalyptus J.

description: awesome breakfast place with authentic Latin food. Great vegetarian and vegan options. Soyrizo was seasoned superbly. Prices good compared to other top rated places! We would come back!!!!
author: Kim N.

description: So many vegan choices! I ordered the vegan breakfast burrito. It was amazing! We also got the plantanos, vegan French toast, sun rise eggs, and a soy mocha. Everyone LOVED their choices! The mocha was yummy, but really sweet. I want to return and try the papusas and some other vegan  dishes.
author: Melissa J.

description: PRO TIP: FOR BREAKFAST, ORDER ONLY FROM LATINO MENU. I know they have an extensive American breakfast menu, and I know that you may be craving some pancakes and bacon, but I swear their Latino breakfast dishes will blow you away so much, you'll forget about pancakes and bacon. The fried plantains are fantastic, and they do something to their black beans that makes it really tasty. ALSO! Order Chai Tea. You won't regret it. :)
author: Trisha D.

description:
I'm a little mystified by all the great reviews for this place. 

We had breakfast here on Sat. morning, and were almost the only ones there. That should have been the big tip-off. Especially since the other place we almost went, (and wished we had) Red's, had a line.

Even though the place was nearly empty, service wasn't great. 
My coffee was served cool, and I had to send it back and request a hot cup. 
To add insult to injury, our server never returned to offer refills. 

I had the breakfast burrito, with ham, queso fresco,eggs, and potatoes. 
While I appreciate that it wasn't greasy, (as can happen with burritos) I expected it to have some flavor. Unfortunately, it was really bland. 

It wasn't inedible by any means, I was just expecting more. Especially after reading such great reviews. 

On the plus side, it was pretty cheap.
author: Amanda G.

description: I loved this place! If I lived nearby it would be a regular spot on my brunch rotation. We had a few different kinds of pupusas, black beans, avocado, and plantains. The plantains were as good as any I've had while traveling in Latin America. Service was good, too!
author: Allison A.

description: The rice beans, salsa, and fried plantains is all you need for your experience here to be delectable.
author: Tony P.

description:
I'm always on the lookout for cute little diners for when I wake up at 11 on a typical Saturday and have a craving for some brunch. 

Sun Rise has quickly jumped to the top of my list. Cheap food (mostly under $10), excellent service and friendly staff all are good signs, and the food didn't disappoint. 

I've always ordered off the Latin American portion of the menu, and both the breakfast burrito and huevos rancheros were solid. The soyrizo on the vegan breakfast burrito was a little boring, but the included salsa made up for it. 

Overall, Sun Rise is one of my regular standbys and an easy recommendation.
author: Scott T.

description:
I have a new favorite thing to order at Sunrise.  A side order of plaintains with a side order of rice and beans.  It comes out as a big plate for like $5.00!  Vegan yumminess!!!

Also, the vegan tamales with that special red sauce are so yummy.   I must admit, I get the vegan tamale every time, no matter what I ordered as my main entree.  It's just one of those things in life that is not negotiable.
author: Rachel D.

description:
The food - delicious
The service - incredibly slow
Our stomachs - feeling a little weird after eating, and for my friend, hurting a couple hours afterwards
The selection - they have vegan options, which I really appreciated that

Overall an okay place to eat (besides the mystery stomach aches). I'll stick to my other brunch regulars.
author: Tasha M.

description: What a way to start the day! I had the plantain plate with cheese pupusas. They seasoned the black beans to compliment the sweetness of the plantains. Nice portions, vegan options, mellow vibe and good service.
author: Lulu M.

description: Hello San Fran! I'm sitting here now at this adorable little hustle and bustle cafe in The Mission. I like it because I can sit here in the corner at a little table for two and spread out with my bacon, eggs, toast, and laptop. It's sunny and cheery, feels like (and is) a neighborhood cafe. It's loud-ish, which adds to the fun and vibe. This is a weekend brunch-time that I'm writing, so might be a bit quieter during the week. The staff is friendly -if just a tad stretched thin! But I've been a server before, so BE NICE TO THEM -they gotta make a living, right? ;D I can't super review the food, cuz only had the classic scrambled eggs, toast, bacon, and potatoes -but it was good. Solid, cooked as I asked (well done, crispy, etc.) and not too greasy. The coffee is hot and freshly made!
author: Annie B.

description:
Had the huevos al gusto with plantains (chose scrambled eggs since easier to work with tortillas). Dang everything was good and hearty - very filling without being stuffed. The pupusas were good as well, just ignore omelettes. The coffee was okay, more on the warm than hot side, and there was no refill or an offer. But, the waitress was the only person working at the time. No worries, since this was during the Mission Street Food fest and there were bound to be waits everywhere.

The place is warm and inviting, with a yellowish paint wall-to-ceiling decor with art "blocks" of all shapes and sizes everywhere. Would return, yep. Only a few blocks away from the 24th St. BART station.
author: Peter L.

description:
Came to this place on a whim with a friend after reading their menu online; the chilaquiles seemed to beckon to me, and having been raised on chilaquiles every other Sunday at my mother's house, this would be quite the mark to meet. Chilaquiles, by the way, are typically crispy tortilla wedges cooked in a mildly spicy red or green sauce, then mixed with (usually) scrambled eggs, some sort of cheese (queso fresco here), and often times one might see lettuce, shredded meat, and/or beans. Here, they are served with just eggs, cheese, and a bit of chorizo.  

Thankfully,the mark it was met. The chilaquiles were slightly crispy, mildly sweet and salty (a good salsa), with a hint of chorizo, and generous eggs. I ordered it with a side of beans for old times sake, and they partnered with them quite well. Paired with a hot cup of coffee this couldn't have been better. The Huevos al Gusto my friend ordered were good too, with the plantains tender and sweet. A winner as well. I highly recommend the chilaquiles... 

My only gripe was that for a friday morning, there was only one person on the floor and 2 big groups besides us, so the service was a little slow, but not bad.
author: Vittorio L.

description: After all the great Yelp reviews this place got, I was expecting a much better meal. I had the chorizo and eggs with black beans. It was ok. It seemed overly salted and there really wasn't anything remarkable about it. The decaf espresso I had was awesome. If you're stuck drinking decaf, you can appreciate how hard it can be to find a decent cup of it. My husband had the breakfast burrito and didn't really like it. I don't know, maybe we caught this place on an off day?
author: Amanda W.

description:
Pretty standard local neighborhood restaurant.  Everything on the menu is good.  The breakfast fare and the standard burgers/sandwiches/Mexican food.  They even have papusas!  Come here to get some breakfast food after a long night out.  I got a breakfast burrito which was pretty good. The chilaquiles were a popular item in the restaurant but it seemed like my friends all got standard breakfast fare which all look good. It's hard to mess up eggs, toast, and sausage. 

This is a place to eat at if you're in the neighborhood but not somewhere you would make a long drive towards.
author: John N.

description: I was looking for a quick quality breakfast and sunrise delivered. The omelette was cooked right and quite tasty. The service was adequate though it seemed like one more person would have been better, and it was kinda my own fault for choosing the seat I did but I wound up sitting right next to a window where they prepared checks and I didn't love having people standing right over me while I was eating. Never-the-less, I'll probably be back soon. Thanks for the nice breakfast
author: Justin D.

description:
Cute breakfast restaurant with great vegan options! 

Oh my, what a gem. The menu was fantastic and clearly labeled vegan options. I went with the soyrizo which came with black beans, rice, and tortillas. The soyrizo was flavorful and crispy yuummmzz and the coffee was delicious. 

Two people in my party ordered hot chocolate and said it was good. Other members in my group had egg dishes and french toast with no complaints. Parking was tricky and watch your meter. Otherwise, the place was run by two people so do not be in a hurry (hence watch your meter!). 

It was really nice to see vegan options outside of  tofu scrambles.
author: Hollie W.

description:
Saturday morning, hangover in full effect, desperately in need of sustenance. What better than a Mexican breakfast to kick-start the day? Lucky for us, Sun Rise was just a short walk away!

I opted for the chilequiles, while my friends opted for just some eggs, bacon & potatoes and the Sun Rise breakfast, which was very similar to eggs benedict, but without the hollandaise. The bacon & eggs were nothing spectacular, but the potatoes (which were requested as "extra crispy") were spot-on. The Sun Rise was pretty bland, definitely not up to its tasty description. My breakfast was the clear winner, and lucky for my breakfast companions, there was more then enough to go around! 

The chilequiles were a huge portion of crispy tortilla chips, mixed together with scrambled eggs and chorizo, and all smothered with a delicious red sauce (like an enchilada sauce), and some queso fresco. It was a truly outstanding dish. Between the 3 of us, we practically licked the plate clean!

Word to the wise - don't stray from the Mexican breakfast portion of the menu and you won't be disappointed!
author: Eve C.

description:
Decent quality but tiny portions.  My omelet was smaller than my hand with only 12 homefries, 3 thin apple slices and one butterfied orange slice.  Yes I counted.  Tiny burnt toast too.  I felt like a giant Gulliver.  The place was so cold that I had to wear my coat the entire time and was still cold.  There were no paper towels in the bathroom.  The only good thing I can say is that my omelet had good flavor.  Yes, all 3 bites of it.

My friend who I ate with said that his food was lousy and I could see it was all watery, and it wasn't soup.

And the final ringer, the price was outrageous for what you got.
author: Scott A.

description: Love Sun Rise Restaurant!  Convenient to BART 24th St. Mission Station ...  Delicious vegan breakfast options .... Wonderful staff ... Indie art on the walls ...
author: Brian W.

description: I'd love to tell you how I enjoyed (or didn't) their food, but to do that I would have to be able to actually enter their restaurant, which isn't possible when they aren't open when they say they are. Yelp says that they are open at 7AM on Saturdays, their sign in the window says that they are open at 7AM on Saturdays, but twice now I have tried to go there and they've been closed at 7:10AM. I peered in the window this morning to se if it looked like they would be opening soon, and all of the chairs were up on the tables and a lady in the back looked at me as if I was the biggest fool in the world for trying to go to their restaurant. I've tried twice now, but probably won't bother with a third attempt.
author: Jonathan G.

description: A much needed yummy breakfast! I ordered both pancakes/eggs and frijolitos/plátanos maduros/crema. Great taste for an even better price. Service is courteous. Only downfall, ordered eggs well done and they arrived over done making it tough to eat.
author: Monica A.

description: I absolutely love this place.  The vegan fajitas are off the hook.  Very filling.  The vegan french toast is also quite good.  The place is great for breakfast food all day.  Unless you speak Spanish pick up orders over the phone can be challenging.
author: Naomi A.

description: So good! My husband and I came for breakfast here twice in our 4 day visit to SF. This place is inviting and everyone working here is very sweet...and they cook up a delicious vegan breakfast burrito.
author: Katie P.

description:
Eh, uninspired review here... 

Here's where I stand on this place:

1) the prices are relatively cheap you can leave here for $20 (for two).
2) I tasted too much soggy spinach taste with my sunrise eggs.
2a) the eggs were fully cooked no yoke left...
2b) the chips were good... 
3) service seemed a little lacking, one girl at another table actually got up to get more coffee, not the sign of awesome service.
4) This isn't a place with big lines... bonus.

I've had much better breakfasts else where on 24th e.g. st francis fountain or papalotes, even last supper club was better although that's on 23rd...
author: Michael S.

description: My new favorite breakfast in San Francisco. Muy autentico. Muy sabor! Had Huevos al Gusto, which came with corn tortillas.  Lovely family run business with authentic Central American style breakfast. Just wish it/I were a couple thousand miles south.
author: Ian R.

description:
I love this place. It's just one of those simple pleasures in life. The staff is really friendly, the food reliably good, the interior is warm and comfortable, and I've never had a problem just walking in and finding a seat. Walk across the street to Philz coffee, and you will definitely have a great morning.

My favorite dish is the Huevos al Gusto.I've posted a photo of the dish, so you can see it above the review.  It consists of eggs (your choice on how it's done) a rice-black beans mix that's tasty, a wedge of cheese, and sweet platanos with sour cream for dipping. Wash it down with a glass of sweet horchata and your in heaven.
author: Lucky G.

description: Totally delicious vegan pupusas and breakfast burritos at really great prices. Non-vegetarian/vegan friends also give this spot a thumbs up! Friendly service. Horchata was too sweet.
author: Jolene T.

description: Excellent! Tried the Huevos Al Gusto and it felt like I was home having a home made breakfast prepared by my mom!
author: Rudy M.

description:
I can't believe this place has four stars. After an all-night long coding session, we hopped on yelp and saw a Latin American restaurant open at 7am Sunday morning. The pictures looked appetizing, and we were hankering for some good ethnic food, so off we went!

Well, the food was NOT appetizing. It was the opposite of appetizing. It was off-putting. While the other three orders were just sub-par, one of our orders was absolutely revolting. Somebody ordered the mushroom omelet and we spent the rest of our breakfast trying to describe how disgusting it was, wishing we didn't taste it. 

I was revolted. It was like, as if I was giving a BJ to a mushroom. And then the mushroom had climaxed and squirt tons of little spores into my mouth. And then spores tried their hardest to impregnate my tongue. 

That's how bad this tasted. 

I even offered a friend $20 cash to finish it off. HE DECLINED.

We were the only four people in the restaurant, and even then we got ZERO service. The waitress took our order, and that was all that we saw of her for the next 45 minutes. No refills on water. Nothing. We had to get up to get her attention. Once to get the check. Once again to pay. And even when we paid, she wouldn't split the check among our cards, forcing us all to pay on one. Next time, I suggest that if you go here with more than one person that has a card, you all sit at different tables. 

Actually, I don't suggest you go here at all. 

P.S. After we reasoned that there is some possibility they didn't know they were serving their customers spoiled mushrooms, we thought it'd be a nice gesture to tell them. The waitress said, in exact quotations, "You didn't like it? I'm sorry." And then we left.
author: Gravity S.

description:
I read about this on a best benedict list and was intrigued.  Also, it apparently has great yelp reviews and fans on facebook (but then again so does Panchita's #3).  So when I say that I think it's overrated, I don't mean it exactly in an insulting way.  The place is super cute, the service is friendly, and the food was solid - the hype is just a little more than warranted.  I wondered as I was eating whether people just want to show they're down with the community by raving about a local hole in the wall non gentrified restaurant.  

Anyway, I thought the chilaquiles were ok, and its cool that they're willing to make it with vegan chorizo, but they're better at San Jalisco (formerly Los Jarritos) and the benedict was adequate but wouldn't make my top 10.  The potatoes were not very good and I dislike Mr. Espresso coffee, so we went over to Philz after for coffee.  

I'd be interested in trying the rancheros, breakfast burritos and maybe a few other items on the menu, and am open to being more impressed.  Go early if you wish to avoid hipsters.
author: Linda L.

description:
These folks have a really interesting and unusual approach to their meals. I order the chilequilles, the ones offered with scrambled eggs, chorizo, queso fresca, tortilla chips and sour cream with fresh salsa and the waitress brings tortilla chips with salsa, sour cream and did I mention tortilla chips? Lots and lots and lots and lots of tortilla chips?

I tuck in believing the eggs and chorizo to be hidden somewhere under that plate-breaking mound of chips and.....nothing; no eggs, no chorizo. Perhaps they are on the other side of the platter, I surmise, wanting to believe the chilequilles of my childhood are somewhere to be found amongst all those tortilla chips. Rotating the platter to begin my quest afresh, I tuck in again from the new angle AND......... still no eggs, still no chorizo.

I attempt to catch the waitress's eye to no avail. She was too busy serving some damned fine looking breakfasts WITH eggs and damned fine looking eggs they were. Oh, and what is that on that young fellow's plate??? It's my missing chorizo!!!

I give up. I surrender. I retreat to the cash register, pay my bill and exit the door to check the menu in the front window, hoping, praying the folks in the kitchen mistook me for some overgrown, very tall, very Texan vegetarian and served me their vegetarian version of chilequilles. My heart sinks as I read the veggie version contains black beans. Whole or mashed, you ask? Why I would have no idea since the special Texas vegetarian version not listed on the menu contains nary a trace of a bean of any stripe, not a single one, zilch, nada, none nestled anywhere among that vast plate of chips.

There is always a first time and a last time for me. Rarely do the two coincide. At the Sun Rise Restaurant, that rarity became reality.
author: John A.

description:
This is a great standard breakfast place. Nothing over the top, but it was fresh and delicious! French toast was tasty and the potatoes were yummy!!! Their bacon was even cooked just right - not too crispy, but not too soft!

 I'll definitely be back.
author: Maggie F.

description:
Not seeing my beautiful friend Amie K in a long time, I jumped at the chance to meet her for lunch; especially at a new place w/ a good brunch. I patiently wait as she gets all cute (not that this cute girl needs any prepping). 

The place is packed so I'm anxious to try their juevos con chorizo. The wait was worth it once I see my lovly brunch mate approach our table for two. 

Chit chat about the latest __________, and that one time ___________, and who said what to whom. Finally the food comes out. 

I get the juevos con chorizo w/ a side of hash and Amie gets the vegan breakfast burrito w/ a vegan papusa. The portions are average (definitely don't expect to take stuff home for another meal). But the food is good and worth coming back for. 

The juevos con chorizo came w/:

Three fresh steamed tortillas, good mexican cheese, salsa, sour cream, black beans, the eggs were scrambbled w/ the chorizo. 

Hash was a golden brown and crisp; perfect w/ tap and ketchup. 

I did have to ask for water a number of times though before inally getting it. 

It was great catching up w/ Amie and we made plans for dinner when I return from HI. Can't wait to regale her about my mis-adventures on the black sand beaches of Kona.
author: Angelo F.

description: This is just a breakfast burrito review FYI...  So this place is charming.  Low key, and homey feel inside, and the staff are polite.  I got the bacon breakfast burrito this time and it was pretty damn good.  The eggs are nice and fluffy which makes a big difference and the bacon is pretty good.  The cheese wasn't totally melted in mine, and the inside was a little dry, which some of their salsa cured.  It's not a grab and go place, so it's more sit down style, but I did dig the breakfast burrito and wanna come back to try the other goods.  Nice neighborhood spot!
author: Gene X.

description: Amazing food. I had the huevos al gusto with plantains. I've been on a two month road trip eating my way across the country in all the foodie cities and this was the best meal I've had. Stick with Latin dishes.
author: Michaela R.

description:
Patient and alluring are my biggest qualities and both was tested quite greatly at this latin usa restaurant. All i wanted was to smoosh plantain and bean into my little mouth after hearing hoop dream hype about Sun Rise. It was only after a long wait to sit, a longer wait to order and flirt, and a gut achingly longest wait to get my foods that i could do so. Oh it was treacherous and cruel of them to make me wait and stare at my neighbor's plates for extended periods of time. even my neighbors seemed to sympathize by giving me strange looks, so even they understood. the mashed black beans were satisfactory after some salting and the sour cream was down right delicious.

maybe i will give them another taste if i have hours to waste and can get that waitress' number ;)
author: Merland S.

description: Overall, the food was really good! The restaurant itself is pretty small and it was packed for a weekday morning! We had a large group and shared all our food. I realllly loved the block of fresh cheese that came w/ everyone's food. I'm not sure what type of cheese it was, but it was good! Close to SFGH!
author: Yumi H.

description: Great ambiance. The art and music and service were great, my eggs were just way overcooked. would not return.
author: Evan R.

description: This past mother's day, I wanted to take my mom on a brunch outing.  We're not big fans of the traditional brunch plates (pancakes, french toast, eggs benedict, sausage/bacon etc.) and wanted something with a Latino flare.  Sun Rise is small eatery, but there was no wait time upon our arrival and our dining experience got started fairly quickly! Their menu showed a great variety and typical Latino breakfast items that my mom enjoys; she opted for the Huevos Rancheros which she hasn't had in months.  She really enjoyed the ranchera sauce, plantains, casamiento, and the quesito fresco.  So simple, yet so delicious.  I chose the Huevos a la mexicana which was scrambled eggs with bell pepper, tomato, and onions; the plate came with a side of black beans and queso fresco.  So yum!!  We can make eggs at home, but these plates oozed with the comforting latin flavors we craved.  This was our first time here, and we left with the hope of coming again to try their lunch/dinner items.
author: Vanessa G.

description: This is a classic 3 star. The atmosphere is humble, but clean. There is one waitress. The prices are reasonable. My breakfast burrito was a good deal at $5. Best part is that the food wasn't greasy. Overall, I won't crave it, but will pass it and say "that place is good!"
author: Andrew K.

description:
The atmosphere is amazing - the vibes are great, and they donate 20% of thier proceeds to local non-profits, like Critical Resistance!  Every Thursday is this awesome event, "Lengua en Salsa" where they donate food proceeds to orgs in the community. Awesome.

The chorizo eggs were AMAZING - but $7.50 for the amount they gave was kinda pithy. My friend ordered two Papusas, which were both PHENOMENAL (Vegetarian). The platano are great - make sure to get em w/ cream + Black Beans!!!
author: Lauren S.

description: We just ate here for brunch about 1pm, the food was amazing! I definitely recommend definitely recommend the pancakes there! My boyfriend had the vegan breakfast burrito and it was delicious! Also, there was no wait and great reasonable prices!
author: Melissa R.

description:
The dr.'s arm has been in an industrial looking sling for a couple of weeks now and it's funny seeing people's reactions but the best was the one from the mariachi at Sun Rise who told us that the last time he was in a sling like that was for trying to hit his wife.

"What?"

"She ducked,"  he said.

"Umm...what?"

Sometimes it's easier to laugh, slip the guy some singles and continue inhaling the vegan french toast in front of you.

Tales of spousal abuse, scattered tables of hipsters and mexicans all dining as one made Sun Rise feel cozy.  This place is right at home on 24th St.  

We had traveled here from reading tales of vegan pupusas.  They did not fail.  I've never even had a meaty pupusa (why does that sound wrong) from my omnivorous days.  Eat them while they're hot because when they cool down they start to lose something in flavor.  Be forewarned, they are not afraid of salt in this joint.

The dr. and I split the french toast and the breakfast burrito and both were satisfying.  I don't know how they got the soyrizo crisp.  In my experience, it's stayed mush no matter how long i cooked it.  While I would have added a tad bit more avocado, the burrito was good.  

Quick, easy, no hassle breakfast.

Please note that if you try to punch your wife though, you will pay dearly.
author: Jen I.

description:
Went here for the first time the other day with a couple old friends. And I'm really glad we decided on this restaurant. 

Granted, it wasn't crowded at all when we went, so the service was excellent and everyone there was incredibly nice. Ordered the vegan fajitas, which were SO GOOD, and incredibly fresh too. Friends had a breakfast burrito and fajitas with prawns and beef, all of which went over great.

I would definitely go here again. Well, I'm definitely going here again.
author: Amber B.

description:
I am so happy to have found this place!
Eating here feels like home!
Huge flavorful dishes (like the "bistek al jugo") served with beans, rice, cheese, and HALF AN AVOCADO!
They are just NOT stingy!

Every plate comes with fresh thick hand made tortillas and the servers are very kind and patient.
They have art hanging on the walls and is a warm and homey environment.
ALSO, where else can you find VEGAN pupusas?!?!? THEY ARE DELICIOUS! Made with zucchini and black beans! yay for pupusas with no cheese!

Will come back many times! It's my go to place now!
author: Anais A.

description:
It's an unusual taqueria because it has vegan options like soyrizo and tofu scramble. I had the breakfast vegan burrito and it was palatable but difficult to finish. Not to mention the service wasn't very efficient either. They never brought out the water/condiments until we asked. I'll give it another shot to try other vegan options but for now you get 3 stars.  

This place is very inexpensive so I might be expecting too much for what I pay. But definitely don't get the coffee here. Go across the street to Philz.
author: saurabh S.

description: Really enjoyable breakfasts on the weekends. Plantains? Queso Fresca? Eggs? Yes please!
author: Sam M.

description:
Yummy vegan Latin American food in the Mission! I went for dinner with a friend when I was back in town, and I had really, really tasty tamales! They had to have been the best tamales I'd ever had. I also had a vegan pupusa and vegan fajitas. It was way too much food, but I had wanted to try both the vegan pupusas and the vegan tamales. And boy am I glad that I tried those tamales!

I haven't been for breakfast or brunch, but it looks like they have great veg options for those meals, too! I'll definitely be stopping by the next time I'm in town!
author: Rose K.

description: After coming back from Costa Rica, we wanted to ease ourselves back into the grind of the city. We looked up a place that would serve Latin breakfast and went with it. A Breakfast Burrito and  Huevos Al Gusto - 2 eggs, mix of rice and black beans, fresh cheese, sour cream, fresh cheese, salsa and choice of avocado or plantain. Not quite what we experienced on our trip, but still our bellies were happy. The prices make my wallet happy too.
author: Tinna H.

description:
I'm glad I went here a second time before writing this review. The first time I ate here was on on New Year's Eve with a group. It was crowded, the service was slow, my meal mediocre, and they forgot to bring out one of the dishes we ordered. We'd already waited too long, so we left without it. What kept me from writing a bad review was the potential I saw in the place, and I'm glad I waited to see that potential realized.

Sun Rise seems to have hit their stride four months later. On my second visit, my boyfriend and I shared their vegan breakfast burrito, vegan fajitas, vegan pupusas with black beans and loroco (flower buds that taste sort of like artichoke), and fried plantains. Everything was super tasty! Aside from the food, it's a great space, wasn't too crowded when we went there for dinner on a Saturday night, and the staff was friendly. The service was still on the slow side, but that was really the only negative. Sun Rise is a lovely little low-key, down to earth spot for vegan (or regular) Central American dishes; a great alternative to Gracias Madre.
author: Jill H.

description:
I really was looking forward to giving Sun Rise five stars. I went for breakfast a few months back and absolutely loved how this unassuming, friendly latin spot served up parfaits, egg whites and a house made soyrizo. All delicious. Not to many spots you can get that in ye old Mission. In fact this might be the only one.

Five stars seemed assured until I returned tonight for dinner. I have no complaints on the food - tofu fajitas that were bursting with flavor, perhaps one of the best mixes of tofu, veggies and refried black beans I've ever had. But they totally lost me on the price. $12 + tax for about as much food as you'd get inside a burrito at any number of other Mission joints. And the three mini tortillas that came with it seemed a little conservative.

Absolutely love the food and delicious veggie options, but I can't give a better rating with prices so high. Get that fajita down a few dollars and I'd be happy to add a star or two.
author: Jason B.

description: Food and service were both wonderful! I got a two eggs breakfast plate with a side of fried plantains, and my gf got the pancakes w/ fruit and powdered sugar.  everything tasted like it was homemade and I was pleasantly surprised when the bill came :) I will be back the next time I'm in the bay...
author: Mikey B.

description:
This is a great place for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.  I had their brakfast this morning - huevos al gusto, and it came with gallo pinto (rice and beans), avocado, Mexican cheese, and sour cream and salsa. Plenty of tortillas as well. Authentically Central American.  The decor (bright colors and photos) on the walls makes it a homey place to eat.  Salsa music in the background definitely brightens your day as well.

We have had dinner here as well - beef steak with tomatos and onions and found it delicious as well.

Prices reasonable.
author: Dan L.

description:
Oh my dear Sun Rise, thanks for the lovely vegan pupusas and tamales you serve! 
In fact, your food is so divine, it has inspired me to write my 1st yelp review! You're warm and comfortable, just like my great-grammy's kitchen used to be...
So far we've tried: black bean and zucchini pupusas (great!), vegan tamales (yum!), and the vegan breakfast burrito w/ soyrizo (big and tasty!)...
Another great thing about you is your huge variety of dishes- plenty for carnivores, vegetarians, and vegans alike. 
See you again tonight   =)
author: Cherilyn C.

description:
I got the background on the lack of staff here at Sun Rise from a friend. But it's not fair to the waitress to have to work an entire cafe by herself on a busy Saturday afternoon (especially while the street food fest was going on...). I know she's working hard, and trying hard but that creates for bad service. We met up with some friends who were already eating here and asked to get menus and order...this was a very long ordeal...and then to get our food took even longer.

I got the pork and cheese pupusas and the fried plantains. come here for the plantains, seriously. soooooo goooooood.

but expect to be here for a while, seriously.
author: Lauren S.

description: We were planning to go to Wise Sons Delii for lunch, a few doors down.  But, there was a super long line and we didn't want to wait.  So, we tried Sun Rise instead.  Super cute with "Latin and American cuisine," the menu said.  Thanks for a delish late breakfast--coffee, Heuvos Rancheros (vegetarian) and Chorizo (not vegetarian, although they have vegan Chorizo!). And, no wait to be seated!!!  :D  Service was just a little slow.
author: Allison P.

description:
This is by far my FAVORITE restaurant in the Mission.  The food is superb, the folks are nice and the prices are good.  I feel good giving these folks my money. They have great Latin American food, breakfast, lunch, pupusas, brunch, American stuff like pancakes and vegan options.  It's kind of on the slow food tip so don't go expecting to rush in and out.
I always get the Huevos al Gusto with plantains, beans and rice and avo, salsa, and this really good fresh cheese.  The pupusas, pancakes and tacos are great too. And good coffee.  And they have really weird, good, random art on the walls.
author: Hilarooo C.

description: This is a great find...luckily the line at Wise Sons was too long.  Sun Rise Latin breakfast dishes are great! Healthy breakfast Burrito, Huevos con Gusto, Huevos con chorizo!  They were all good!  The place is also unbelievably easy on the wallet. Good service too...they're just 1 person short on weekends when it seems to get plenty busy.  I'm a fan!
author: Ramon L.

description:
Whenever I think about the soyrizo breakfast burrito at Sun Rise Restaurant, I want to move to San Francisco. The soyrizo, the crispy potatoes, whatever else was in there...definitely the best breakfast burrito of my life.

Plus, Sun Rise Restaurant is adorable and makes me happy to be inside, and they have plantains. What else could you possibly need?
author: Maeve C.

description:
The other day I was wishing I had a breakfast burrito genie and then I met Alba, the owner of Sun Rise Restaurant. Wish granted!

I love this neighborhood place. For reals. The food is amazing and generally will take a hot minute to get to the table, but its totally worth it. The chilaquiles and breakfast burrito is so tasty and can be easily shared with another person if you add a small side like the platanos fritos. My suggestion is to order them "maduros", extra ripe with a side of crema (sour cream). 

Ms. Alba and her staff are super sweet and make you feel like your at home even when the place is packed.
author: Maria A.

description:
Solid food, great prices, comfortable environment

Would not go here for the coffee, but Im spoiled.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Stopped in here in whim and was not disappointed.  Not a taqueria, so be ready to sit down and order.  Place appears to be family run, great assortment of dished both "Latin" and "American" so all tastes can be met.

Will def go back when in the neighborhood.
author: Bruce R.

description:
Sunrise is spectacular! I go here on sundays for breakfast as often as I can. The food is great and the service is even better. They have a young woman serving the approx 15-20 tables in there all by her self, and she's always attentive, friendly and never mess up your order no matter how busy they get. 

The interior is always interesting as they feature new local artists all the time. It seems every time I go in there they have new art up. This place is a goldmine on those sunday mornings when you want your grease fix, and don't want to deal with the hour long waits everywhere else good in the mission.
author: K D.

description:
An excellent choice for brunch in the mission. 

Good prices, generous portions and great service.

I highly recommend the Huevos al Gusto with plantains.
author: Spiferina P.

description:
Yea, this place is awesome.  Brunch on a Sunday with no wait to be seated?  Cool, inspiring, and fresh art on the walls?  Smiling service and a relaxed atmosphere?  And a robust menu sure to satisfy everyone in your party.  I'm probably going to end up being a regular since there were quite a few dishes that sounded great.  Besides, the interior is just comfy.

My friend had the chilaquiles, I had the sunrise (poached eggs, tatos, spinach, bacon), and my friend's kid had eggs, pancakes, and bacon.  The portions were generous and the food tasty.  The bill was easy on my wallet, too.  Oh, and their horchata is great, too.

Yea, I had to go to the counter to pay, but so what?  I thought the service was just perfect, really and truly.
author: Criz S.

description: Three stars. It was a delicious vegan breakfast burrito, but the presentation was lacking, it was literally a giant log on a plate, no salad or even attempt at making the plate look nice. It was cheap, it came out to 7 bucks for a really big portion. I passed on the coffee as a snobby coffee fan (I saw Mr. Espresso though, which is an average roaster, so it's probably not terrible). Ambience was a perfect relaxed Sunday morning feel, not fancy whatsoever, but when you're eating a breakfast burrito or eggs who wants fancy?
author: Patrick D.

description:
The trick with this place is simple: order Mexican food, not American.

The first time I went here I tried one of their regular American omelets.  It sounded yummy but was bland.  The next time I had a vegan soyrizo omelet, and woo hoo, it was so freakin' yummy!!!

I highly recommend the papusas (the bean and cheese and the cheese are particularly yummy).  And they are cheap!!!  

But really, everything I've ever ordered from here that was Mexican food or Mexican-inspired was delicious.  The regular old boring stuff you can get anywhere leaves much to be desired.  When in Rome!

Also, really yummy coffee.  I had a latte or something and it was one of the best I've ever had.  Though, of course, Philz is right around the corner...
author: Sivan B.

description: I had a godawful breakfast there this morning. Horrible, greasy hash browns, avocado had "turned," and they really do not know how to poach an egg.  Next time we go for a mid-week before-school breakfast, we'll just return to the excellent Red Cafe.
author: Kathy R.

description:
Mimosas are effing huge!  6.50 but made with fresh oj and are fairly strong.  They come in what appears to be a 20 oz glass!

We had the huevos al gusto with plantains, and an order of flautas, both were fantastic!  Good crowd and cool mission coffee mugs!  Wish my food came a little faster, I woulda given them a 4.5 or 5!
author: Shawn A.

description: All the food I've had here has been delicious. This morning I had the best pancakes evar with bananas and walnuts. The chilaquiles were great too. I'm not so hot on the coffee-based beverages though. You're better off waiting until after breakfast and going across to Phil's IMHO.
author: Rowan N.

description: I've only been for breakfast and pupusas and it's never disappointed! Conveniently down the street from BART too.
author: Maria F.

description:
This place was pretty crowded on a Sunday morning, which was a good sign. The bad sign: Only one waitress and two chefs. Which meant that it took forever for anything to get done. I never got my water refilled once. The breakfast food was good, but just your standard Mexican brunch food , and nothing special, and certainly not worth the wait.

It's not as popular, but I would highly recommend El Delfin right nearby for real Mexican home(y) cooking.
author: Mark A.

description:
They have the BEST chilaquiles in San Francisco. I like the fact that the eggs and chorizo are spread out throughout the tortillas rather than putting them just on top like most restaurants do.

They have pretty good vagan options and a nice selection of beers. 

You can get a 24 ounce beer from El Salvador called Regia for $7. good stuff.
author: Rigo H.

description:
Was turned away from St. Francis down the street, (they were too b.z.) so ended up here, and glad I did.

They have traditional american b'fast fare, which I was going for even though it was close to 2:00pm, but opted for the chilaquilas...

I used to make this mexican dish which resembles kind of a mashed up
enchilada. I did order this at another mexican restaurant which i can't remember the name of (off 23rd and Valencia???), and theirs was good but a bit too spicy.

But Sun Rise's was a bit different, the tortilla chips retained a bit of crunch that complemented the meal well. My date's chorizo satisfied, and our side of plantains, i say "platanos", (i'm half latino), were sweet and scrumptious.

So many good places on 24th!!!
author: wayne s.

description: Best breakfast berito I ever had and it was vegan as well.  The pancakes were incredible and I am looking for reasons to go back as soon as possible.
author: Robert J.

description: I loved this place.  I had lunch here with my good friend, Linda the Great.  How great is she?  She's so great, she makes Alexander the Great look like Alexander the Wuss!  We usually have lunch once a month, but we've both been busy and haven't had lunch for awhile. It was my turn to pick the restaurant, and I found a Mexican place on Yelp(Valencia Street).  We went there and her Greatness took one look around, and said that it didn't look clean, and it smelled bad.  Hey, when I'm rich and famous, she's going to be my food taster!  So, we wandered down 24th Street(and who doesn't love 24th Street???)  We looked into windows of restaurants and checked out their menus. Sun Rise Restaurant was packed, and the menu looked great!  I had the Huevos a la Mexicana(Mexican eggs) and her Greatness had Lomito al Jugo(steak, rice, black beans, avocado and salsa).  Muy bueno!(very good!).  They gave us hot, freshly made tortillas that were soooooo good!  The service was wonderful!  And OMG, the prices were so reasonable!
author: Blondie R.

description: This place is amazing! It's a tiny hole in the wall with great food! My boyfriend got a vegan French toast made with soy milk & tofu, delish! I got the mushroom with Brie omelette. The food is fresh and has vegan dishes, amazing. This place has the best soy lattes I've had in a very long time! It was so good I had to order another one to go! If you're around this area, definitely stop in for some delicious grub or at least a latte!!!
author: Shana O.

description:
Good food in good portions for a good price. That's what I like! 

Came here for brunch and I had the Huevos al Gusto because it had platanos and I love that stuff. I enjoyed everything else it came with (mmm.. beans.) and cleaned up the entire plate. I arrived hungry and left feeling like a fat-ass. I don't know about ordering the classic American stuff on the menu but I'd probably come back for the Latin American breakfast, and probably order the same thing.
author: Zell C.

description:
The vegetarian chilaquiles were stingy on the soyrizo, but hey, it's chilaquiles.  You can't beat crispy tortilla chips topped with cheese, eggs, salsa, refried beans, and sour cream.  It's every bit as delicious (and bad for you) as it sounds.

The most striking part of the meal, though, was a bright red drink called fresco de chan.  It's kind of like strawberry juice, with seeds in the glass.  So sweet it felt like drinking smooth candy. (I mean that as a compliment).
author: angela n.

description:
THIS IS MY NEW Q.

First morning in my new neighborhood. I am EXHAUSTED after my moving weekend. Hardly able to get out of bed. By 3:00, boyfriend and I are ready to move our asses out the door to find some breakfast.

We didn't just find breakfast, though... We found the Mission version of Q! BETTER than Q!!! They have mock meat, and multiple tofu scrambles! Veggie and vegan fare all over the menu! 

Oh, and regular stuff, too...

And they're just about halfway between the bf's and my new place! With no special ordering involved! Which is GREAT because I have a feeling I'm going to be coming here a LOT on mornings when my brain can hardly handle simple tasks like speech and involuntary muscle and organ coordination, let alone SPECIAL ORDERING!

Holy exclamation points.

This is the kind of joint where a dietarily challenged girl and her meat-and-potatoes guy can enjoy a meal together without wondering if the other is going to run right home after, crouch by the refrigerator, and binge like a ballerina (see Cafe Gratitude: http://www.yelp.com/biz/GGgBRSa6saWrWNUtjdgHsg#hrid:A2ZjbfYHKSmURmaUyYhlSg).

Hooray for happy breakfasts. Eaten with scantily clad Latin ladies dancing around on flatscreen TVs in the background... 

Wait... WTF?
author: Lisa T.

description:
Hence the name, their breakfast menu is the highlight, offering standard American and Latin American influenced dishes.  Surprisingly, there's a few vegan options, including vegan chorizo.  I enjoyed the art on the walls, but the waitress kindly noted that they were merely for decoration, not for sale.  

An anomaly of sorts, lacking the usual line and hipster vibe, it's what makes Sun Rise an excellent choice for that down-home weekend brunch in the Mission.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
No waiting for a table on Sunday Morning.
No problem bringing in our coffee from down the street at Dynamo.

Chilaquiles for my girl and me, veggie for her, full of chorizo goodness for me. Sides of spinach and plantain to modulate the flavorsome excellence of the main dish. Attentive, friendly service even as the place filled up.

Inexpensive and delicious. We'll be back here.
author: Lex L.

description:
I trust the opinion of my friends. Unfortunately, sometimes friends have conflicting tastes.

A sweet charmer had some business to attend to at Philz, so after I wandered around the Mission for a while (hello Aquarius Records!), we reconnected and aimed ourselves toward breakfast before hitting the road for lands southern. As it was right in the neighborhood and highly esteemed by a friend, we stopped at Sun Rise Restaurant for a bite.

Being in the Mission, I decided to do as the Missionaries do. That is to say, I ordered a Mexican breakfast with eggs, black beans, corn tortillas, queso, and salsa. She ordered a tuna melt with fries, not being in the mood for breakfast.

My food was passable. Unremarkable, and certainly not bad, but passable. Her sandwich smelled like the tuna had come from a can opened and left on the counter the previous day... and the tuna was completely ungarnished. Hint, folks, a little mayo or something? The fries, well, let's just say that multiple impotence references were made. Greasy, salty, and completely flaccid. No, really, I've seen dead fish with more rigidity and structural integrity. After finishing what we were going to eat of our meal, the waitress ignored us, making it difficult to pay our bill and leave. I eventually went up to the counter to pay there.

We left wandering what the appeal of Sun Rise is. Perhaps the vegan options are their strength. Perhaps we were there on amateur cook day. I'm not sure, but neither of us was impressed. So I don't plan on going back to Sun Rise. But that's OK, I'll keep my friends.
author: Paul B.

description: I'm vegan, and it's so difficult to find brunch options for vegans.  The vegan french toast w/ fruit was really good! The staff was very, very friendly as well.  It gets four stars instead of five just because of the wait for our food and for the bill.  Overall, great experience!
author: Amanda R.

description: Sun Rise has a great breakfast with a Latin flair.  The black beans and rice and the plantain were delicious!  The coffee was better than most breakfast spots.  We're going back for dinner---
author: Barbara P.

description: I got the Chilaquiles.  I really didn't care for it at all.  The eggs were hard to spot and when I did locate them, they looked like sad little tatters of some flag.  Perhaps I like a different style.  And I wasn't so keen on the service.  My friend never got her diet coke.  I had to ration sips of water because I clearly was not getting a refill.  My side of hash browns had to be requested again after my meal arrived.  Overall, a lackluster experience.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Yo! This place have some very delicious vegan options!

Try the papusas and chilcinas (sp?) (elaborate nachos).

Service was helpful and friendly. Atmosphere is laid back. 

Great Sunday morning date, with a beautiful lady.
author: John W.

description: Delicious! Get the mushroom and Brie omelette with a side of fried plantains. Coffee is good too!
author: Savannah W.

description: Another great , inexpensive place in the mish for breakfast and ginourmous mimosas (16oz)
author: G K.

description:
I just had a great breakfast here, and I feel so lucky that Sun Rise is a block away from my house.  I had the huevos al gusto with plantains.  Eggs over medium and really cooked to perfection, the yolks ran all over my black beans and rice yum yum. The plantains were sweet and crispy and the salsa accompanying the dish was lovely as well.  My husband ordered the huevos rancheros also with plantains.  He loved them as well saying they were perfectly spiced not greasy or oversalted as they can often be.
 OJ was really good and served in a HUGE glass. The horchata was a total revelation, thicker and less sweet than most- also served in a large glass.  The service was very quick and pleasant at about 12:00 on Saturday.  We had no wait whatsoever.  We will definitely be back!
author: sabrina m.

description:
i really quite enjoy sunrise.  quite a whole lot as a matter of fact.

even though the oh-so-popular st. francis is much closer to my apartment, i'll always choose sunrise over st. francis.

i've had huevos a la mexicana, the spinach and eggs, egg & pancake combo, eggs benedict... a few other things, too.  and everything has been excellent.  it's a latin american restaurant but they have some non-latin american items if you don't fancy having beans and salsa in your breakfast.  i think this is a great place to eat following a night of drinking because it's just greasy enough to soak up the remaining booze in your veins but still has some good protein and junk to make it seem healthy.

a few things to note:
- you seat yourself
- have patience as there's usually just one gal working the whole restaurant (this is a good time to practice living in the moment)
- you'll likely need to ask for your check or just go to the counter to pay

head to philz for coffee after you eat and wander through the mission if it's sunny... duh, it's always sunny in the mission.
author: Lauren P.

description: Love love Sunrise. Heuvos al gusto and Chilaquiles are my favs. Staff are sweeties too!
author: Steph N.

description:
Myself and a few other friends had breakfast here on Saturday, the last meal of my friend's single life before his wedding later that afternoon. That's not likely true, actually, as he's the sort to be constantly eating, and I bet he put down a burrito immediately before the proceedings. But I digress. 

The food here was fair to midland, but what killed me - and why I doubt I'll find myself back there - was the service. There wasn't anything wrong with it, per se; the problem was that there was only one person to attend to everyone in the restaurant. I don't think she was so much slow as overwhelmed. I've never worked in a CA restaurant and never been a restaurant owner, and I know there's more to hiring someone than strictly hourly pay, but is the money you're saving by not hiring someone else worth all the trouble? I doubt it. 

I had a pancake combo - pancakes plus scrambled eggs, hash browns, and a sausage that looked like no other I've had - not a disc, not a tube. It was tasty, as were the pancakes, whereas the eggs and taters were pretty run of the mill. They might have been more inspiring had I ever been able to get a coffee refill, but that wasn't worth extending my breakfast another 20 minutes. We had tuxes to don!
author: Ian M.

description: I came here for breakfast while visiting SF with a friend of mine... walking in I felt like I was walking into a little restaurant in someones house, I felt right at home... food was great (and I'm not a breakfast person - at all) service was great... if I am in SF again I will have this on my list of places to go for sure
author: Frank E.

description:
I went to Sun Rise Restaurant immediately after I arrived in San Francisco. It was one of the first places that popped up when I searched "vegan breakfast" on the yelp app. 

I ordered the vegan breakfast burrito. It was delicious. Inside the burrito was soyrizo, roasted potatoes, avocado, and black beans. For some reason when reading the menu I thought the roasted potatoes, salsa, and avocado came on the side, but they were inside. At first I was disappointed because I just had a burrito on a plate and nothing else, but once I realized they were inside of the burrito I was fine. Not the restaurant's fault... I blame a certain Seattle vegan restaurant who's breakfast is enough food to feed a giant for tricking me into thinking I need that much food. I'm a small lady, not a beast, so a burrito is just fine thank you! 

My boyfriend got the vegan french toast and a vegan tamale which he said was the "best vegan tamale ever." I tasted it and it was very good. I have never had another tamale in my life so I have nothing to compare it to, but I would totally order in again.

From my experience, Sun Rise is a good place to go for breakfast. The restaurant was cute and clean and the waitress was nice.
author: Jen H.

description:
I'm pretty shocked that no one has a reviewed this place yet! It's a smallish, home-y, family-run type of brunch spot, in the heart of the mission on 24th, right across the street from Phil's Coffee. Honestly, I probably wouldn't have known about it either, but my boyfriend used to live right above it, and he was the one to actually discover it. 

Sunrise is one of those places that offers a standard brunch menu with a Latin American twist, and frankly, it really works for them. They make great pancakes, and you can order them with fresh strawberries or bananas. I've also enjoyed the vegan chorizo scramble several times, and while I'm generally not big on fake meat, their vegan chorizo (or, "soyrizo" as some call it) was truly a cut above most of the fake meats out there.

As far as I'm concerned, the most note-worthy item on their entire menu is the Fresco de Chan, listed under the beverages...it's this incredibly refreshing fruit drink, and I don't even know what to compare it to...it's a bright fuchsia color, it's full of little floating seeds, and it has a slightly gelatinous texture to it, and sort of a "tropical" sweet taste...sounds odd, I know, but trust me, it's DELISH! We could never figure out what the heck it was made out of, so we finally asked our server one morning, and she told us it was just the juice of a popular Salvadorean (?) fruit (for which she could offer no English translation). I still can't really wrap my mind around what it might be, but hey, maybe it's more fun that way!
author: Shannon R.

description: Standard food. Took more than 30 minutes to get my food when the place was moderately busy. Had the eggs dutches. Meh ...unenthused
author: Chris A.

description:
The boyfriend and I went here for a late breakfast today, around 3, since it's like 4 blocks from our house and was on his way to work. The place was totally empty when we went in, but it was sunny and cheerfully decorated. The menu is relatively small, but seriously: everything on it looks good. 

My orange juice was fresh-squeezed, his horchata was excellent, and both came in big glasses. He ordered the pancake combo: their pancakes are the thin, crepe-esque kind. The bacon was perfectly cooked. The dish came with lots of butter on the side. I got the mushroom & brie omelette, and while it was very well-made, I didn't really dig the combination of flavors. That might just be a personal thing, though. My omelette came with perfectly-cooked hash browns and buttered toast with what I believe was home-made strawberry jam. My only real complaint about my order was it came with a few pieces of fruit, and all of them were overripe and kind of yucky. Definitely not something to remove a star over.

The bill came up to just about $20, and we left stuffed and satisfied. We'll be back.
author: Lynae Z.

description: I've only been here twice, but both experiences were fantastic! Really good food, good prices, a surprising amount of vegan & vegetarian options (vegan breakfast burrito, hollaaaa!), interesting art on the walls, and really friendly service. The second time I was here for Sunday brunch, the place was packed and the entire restaurant was alive with World Cup chatter and friendly hellos. Definitely a great community feel - love it!
author: Sam S.

description: An average breakfast burrito with sausage. They seem very proud of their couple of third place contest/poll placements. Something to inspire improvement, I guess.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Not much to offer at this restaurant, especially with so many better places on 24th.  On my last visit, service was incredibly slow (despite the place being empty) and everything had to be requested twice.  

And the food only made the experience worse.  We left full, but entirely unsatisfied, just hoping to be hungry to get that taste out.  It's possible other items on the menu are better, but it's not worth the risk of going back.
author: Shanan A.

description:
Sun Rise Restaurant is an inauspicious nook on 24th St. that serves up classic American breakfasts as well as some Latin American specialties.  The menu has something for everyone, tofu scramble, omelets, chilequiles, sandwiches, salads, and dinner options that range from tilapia to pork chops and grits to steak ranchero.

After tossing back some sun rise drinks up the street during the world cup games, we were in need of some subsentence. I didn't expect much from Sun Rise but they won me over with their yummy chilequiles sin huevos ($7.50) doused in a chorizoy red sauce and toped with queso fresca and crema; they were an ovaphobe's breakfast delight. The menfolk were also pleased with their omelet and  hash browns ($6.95), and combo breakfast that came with 2 pancakes, bacon, and 2 eggs.  

Our waitress was very sweet and tended to our needs while the basic food served quickly (no wait for a weekend brunch table) hit the spot. 3.5 stars.
author: Candice L.

description: I was in town for a day and wanted to try a vegan friendly restaurant, so I went to Yelp and found Sun Rise.  Reviews sounded great.  Menu looked solid.  Then we went there and found the atmosphere very charming, the service somewhat lacking, and the food kind of plain.  I mean, I'm really glad they have vegan options, but it really was a disappointing experience.
author: Derek H.

description: As a Nicaraguan, I'm already used to this style of food, but I think anyone would appreciate its freshness and authenticity. One of my favorite brunch spots in SF. Delicious!!!!
author: Anon A.

description:
I was REALLY hoping to be the first to review this place but my husband beat me to it.... He'll get it later. I know where he lives!!
.
After spending so much time on 24th, I can't believe I've walked past this place so many times. Even more shocking....the little place was near empty at 6pm on a Sunday!!

This is definitely my kind of place. We are both vegetarians and have exhausted our list of exclusively vegetarian restaurants in this city. Especially in the Mission. So, every once in awhile we come upon a place that has a pretty extensive vegetarian menu and dive in this new one, head first! There are even a handful of vegan items such as vegan chorizio and tofu. There are even corn and rice pupusas for those with celiac / gluten intolerance. Their house hot sauce (Tapitio) is also gluten free


Overall, there are so many types of options from breakfast, (starting @ 7 am and served til" closing ) Tofu pesto, eggs benedict,, 3 different vegetarian omelets. The usual type of fare....Chilaquiles, Huervos Rancheros or Al Gusto if you prefer. Pancakes, toast, fruit , granola, eggs florentine, eggs duchess..... There are still sandwiches , salads and for dinner you can get the New York steak for 14.95. Their highest priced dinner on the menu. There is so much variety I could go ON, ON and still ON!!! Camarones, Tilapila, Milanesa.

For this particular dinner, I chose a cheese and spinach pupusa and I think it may have been the best damn pupusa I have ever had in my life. For one thing, I ordered a rice pupusa and was not charged extra. Another, they were extremely generous with both potion sizes and better ingredients used. Many, many other pupusa to choose from too...

Both food and beverages are priced quite well.  
Breakfast & 2 pupusas = $11.50
2 beers & 1 coke =          $7.00

Twentyish with a nice tip came to 
$30.00..... Not too shabby
 

One more cool thing....Every 2 months the owner participates in the 2nd Saturday art walk and the walls of the restaurant are covered in eclectic art, all by local artists. This restaurant is very cute, clean and simple but with a very homey and comfortable feeling.

Embarrassingly enough I did not get the owners name but she was our food server as well. She was on it!! Very accommodating, very personable and seems great overall. I guess I'll get her name the next time we head back to Sunrise
author: Tamara S.

description: Consistently good food, good value, and super friendly service. Food is in fact "Latin American" as I cannot put my finger on which country influences the menu the most. But it's great.
author: Fattfreddie F.

description: I stopped by Sunrise Cafe to grab a quick breakfast burrito.  The food is amazing and the burrito was huge!  I split it with my roommate while we swapped stories of what happened the night before.
author: Nick H.

description: Love this place. They have a really good and fresh breakfast burrito. I've been coming here for the past 3 days. Try the sausage breakfast burrito! The women who work there are really nice too. Really an great place. Would love to try it for a later meal sometime.
author: Sean P.

description: Waitress is hella nice and doesn't give my friend and I a judgy face for getting drunk off mimosas at 7am on a Tuesday, plus there are vegan options.
author: k h.

description: Got breakfast on a whim. I ordered their 'Sunrise Eggs.' 2 poached eggs, bacon, avocado and spinach on an english muffin. As many reviewers have cited before, the wait for food was pretty long. So long, in fact, that by the time my eggs came I was hungry enough that I was ready to eat whatever, rather than complain that my eggs were overcooked, and the rest of the food was cold. For nearly $10 I would expect at least one egg of two to be poached correctly. Food aside, the interior was charming.
author: Jake W.

description: when i first saw this places i didn't exactly have the highest hopes for it given that its basically a hole in the wall you wouldn't think of going into. but it completely took me off guard and blew me away.First the places was very clean and welcoming inside, The service was great. And the food was absolutely amazing. I had the vegan sopas and the vegan tamale. They were both exception. Im not the big fan of mexican food but their food changed my mind.
author: Cheyenne C.

description: no frills, latin american home-cookin'.  the asada steak could use a bit more flavor; i'll be back to try other items on the menu!
author: Dennis D.

description: As soon as you walk in, you feel right at home. Service is friendly and the place is very "homey." And the food quality will not let you down! Seriously a wide variety of hearty plates. Recommendations: the SOPA DE POLLO comes with big delicious chicken pieces and vegetables. The ZUCCHINI PUPUSAS are really cheap ($2.50) and taste sooooo good! Highly recommend =D
author: Marissa P.

description: I don't know what the hype is all about, but I've tasted better food (at least Pupusas) from other Salvadorian Restaurants. The service was mediocre but the personality of our waitress leaves something to be desired. Not once did she say hello or thank you or asked us if we needed anything else... this from a waitress lacking in looks. A great personality can do wonders when short on looks. Go to La Santaneca de la Mission..much better place.
author: Will V.

description:
dear sunrise, i. love. you. 

yes, there is usually a wait. yes, the service is slow. yes, it will take a while to get your food. is it worth it? HECK YES. 

if you are impatient, just avoid this place, really. no one wants to hear your whining and moaning especially on a lovely sunday morning when the place is at maximum occupancy. this is not a place to get all holier than thou, snap your fingers (who does that? really?) or expect some special service that only you seem to know about. the waitresses have never been anything but extremely friendly to me and fellow diners.. i would even go as far to say that i sometimes feel like a guest in their home;  it's that comfortable in there. 

and if you go on a sunday super stressed out, leave it at the door. just relax, WAIT, and prepare for your palate to be rewarded with some of the most amazing latin american food. well, the best vegan latin american food.. hands down. 

attention vegans!

they make the best soyrizo ever! i always get the veggie tofu (tofu scramble type deal with veggies, toast, and homefries), a side of soyrizo and a vegan tamale. my boyfriend gets the soyrizo burrito every time and we've turned several of our non-veg friends onto it.

i try to come every sunday after dance class, and every sunday i end up looking 4 months pregnant after all the food i stuff into my poor (but totally happy) belly completely voiding the hard work i did in class. again, is it worth it? most definitely.
author: darcy a.

description:
Noon on a sunny Sunday: Biked past the 20-minute wait at St Francis, skipped the 45-minute wait at Boogaloos, walked into a virtually-empty Sun Rise, had a killer brunch: eggs, beans, rice, cheese, plantains, tortillas and coffee for $10. Seriously great and seriously underappreciated.

To the folks who are giving this place low ratings: Look, this a Latin-American restaurant! Order Latin-American cuisine! Do not order the mushroom omelette. Do not order the granola yogurt. You will not be happy with the outcome. This is not a Denny's. The Mission is not the suburb you came from. Wake up and smell the huevos al gusto, or go home.
author: Tim J.

description: The food was delicious, plus you can get really tasty Vegan food.  I ordered the Vegan fahitas and my friend said that the vegan pupusas were delicious!  Check it out!
author: Lily B.

description:
So my GF had just arrived on an overnight flight from DC and wanted to get some BK in the MD. So we hit up the yelperooni and sure enoughh got this reco. As always we trusted our fellow yelpers and rolled out to the sun rise spot on a nice sunny afternoon.

BIG MISTAKE! 

DO NOT get the eggs benedict! Its more like eggs orange sludge coveredness! My GF was all like OMG WTF?! IT was sooo disgusting we couldnt handle it!

that and the food came like 5 hours late!

Im sorry, Im sticking to the Fountain for my brunchy munchies!
author: Bobby F.

description: Great Price, Good people working with the community, art, vegan friendly and the best pupusas is Northern California!!
author: Jesus C.

description:
One of the best breakfast burritos in the mission. Nice service as well. The ingredients are good and it comes through in the taste. Not as greasy and fatty as most mission burritos. 

And it's right across from Phils!
author: Jakob S.

description:
chilaquiles are pretty much breakfast nachos.  you know that right?

so so good, the nachos stay crispy even in the salsa type juice and the soyorizo and egg combo is just heaven.  not greasy at all!  it was my first time and i've been thinking about it ever since.  i compared it to the real chorizo my friend was having and couldn't tell the difference!

surprisingly, their lattes are also really oustanding.

i'm definitely coming back!
author: Josie M.

description: Nice brunch spot in the Mission.  Laid back - in a good way.  Tasty and crispy morning potatoes.
author: Becky G.

description:
I don't want to rave too much about Sunrise on 24th because I love that I can always walk in and grab a table with no problems, but really, I love this place. 

I've had breakfast here many times and pupusas for dinner once-- never had a bad experience. I recommend chilequiles (think breakfast nachos--yum!)  or huevos al gusto with platanos for breakfast/brunch. They have a wide range of options on their menu, making carnivores, vegetarians and vegans happy.

They have local artists featured on the walls and the waitresses are very sweet and accommodating.  The crowd is unassuming and I like the tables by the windows because the sun comes in and warms you up as you watch passerbys on 24th. A comfortable and comforting place.
author: Chris L.

description: Service is friendly- like you went to breakfast at your aunt's house, and the food is delicious and simple.  Huevos al Gusto- delish.
author: Allie L.

description:
Would definitely eat here again!!!!

It's a 1st come 1st served situation - sometimes there's a wait, but they move people in and out quickly.

My friend had the Hueves a la Mexicana - so yum!
I had the Platanos, frijoles negros y crema - so perfect, just what I wanted!

Get coffee at Philz then come over here :)

Also, their mimosas come in pint glasses.  I truly enjoyed watching the waitress pour the thing halfway full of champagne, then top it off with some fresh-squeezed OJ.  Highlight!!!
author: Sara P.

description:
I have been a regular at Sunrise on saturday's ever since it opened.  However, it seems that the quality of the food is gradually on decline.

For example:  A few weeks ago, the lettuce on my salad was starting to rotten.

On different days:  My pancakes had a sour taste to them. My chilaquiles had been salty to the point where I could not enjoy them.

I have noticed that they have a loyal clientele on weekends.  Mostly local families of 4 or 5 per table.  However it seems that the owner does not realize this because she has not hired a helper and there is no way that two cooks and herself can run the business alone on weekends.  You can easily be waiting 20 minutes for her to take your order and another 35-45 minutes to get your breakfast.  It is also a task to get coffee refills.

I really do hope this place improves.
author: Carlos M.

description:
The service is friendly and fast, the owners run the show. Open at 7am, unlike the other 24th St breakfast restaurants. 

Many items are homemade. Especially all soups (although none are veggie) and the strawberry jam for toast.

There are TONS of vegetarian options, and the prices put it less than 50% of the bill at the St. Francis. Vegan Chorizo, tofu, and the usual bevy of meaty Salvadorian and Latino foods spot the menu. They are not limited though; Hollandaise sauce appears with Smoked Salmon to round things out. 

We had a great time, an omelet and Spinach Pupusas for dinner, 3 drinks and the bill was 20 bucks!

Really worth checking out!
author: Freud R.

description: How can you not root for a little Salvadorean dive that decided to paint the walls yellow and serve breakfast all day (bless their hearts)?  The results may not quite best Los Jarritos, but then, they're not going for the hearty, raucous diner vibe either.  At any rate, you'll find lots of vegan options (like soyrizo breakfast burritos), and great tamales and dinner dishes as well (case in point: the shrimp fajitas).  And don't forget some fresco de chan (basically fresh-made strawberry juice).  Easily overlooked in the jumble of odd and colorful shops on 24th St, which is probably why it still has a hipster-free, family-oriented clientele of locals (for now, anyway).
author: Wes M.

description: Love their pupsas! I would recommend their vegan fajita plate. Very tasty! The vegan breakfast burrito was kind of boring. They had a few other vegan options... vegan french toast and vegan tamales. Altogether a good brunch!
author: Philip R.
